question: If an Applicant/Authorised Person wants its FSP to cover Regulated Activities for both Spot Commodities and conventional assets (like Securities or Derivatives), can the Regulator lower or waive fees so they don’t add up twice, and when can it do that?
gold_answer: Yes, in the situation where an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Spot Commodities, it needs FSRA approval for its FSP to allow it to conduct the Regulated Activity for both asset types. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] When fees are being considered for those conventional and Spot Commodity-related Regulated Activities, the fees may be treated as not cumulative if the FSRA uses its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, particularly in light of the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] Separately, the Regulator has a general ability to reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) at any time, as long as it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Putting these together, the Regulator can apply that fairness-based relief in a way that avoids fees stacking up across both asset types when the case circumstances justify it. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]

question: When the Listing Authority concludes, after an enquiry into a complaint or allegation, that the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not covered by the Rule 7.2.2 disclosure exemption, how should the Listing Authority proceed under Rule 7.2.1, and what specific confirmations and timing details would an ‘aware letter’ typically require from the Reporting Entity if the information should have been Disclosed earlier?
gold_answer: Where the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to decide the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and does not fall within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption from disclosure, it will require the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] If the Listing Authority considers the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may issue an ‘aware letter’ as a follow-on step. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] In that aware letter, the Listing Authority would typically (a) identify the information at issue and state the relevant date it was Disclosed, and then (b) ask the Reporting Entity to address whether it considers the information to be Inside Information, using the reasonable-person/price-effect framing described in the template. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity answers that it is Inside Information, the letter generally seeks timing and context: when the Reporting Entity first became aware of it, including the time and circumstances of becoming aware of the key contents. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] It also asks why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension earlier, with specific commentary on Rule 7.2.1, and requests confirmation of compliance with the Markets Rules, particularly Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28]

question: When the Regulator issues a written collateral notice to a Captive Insurer requiring assets to be made available, how is the maximum value of those assets capped by reference to the “lower of” test, and how is the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount determined for (i) a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company and (ii) a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company?
gold_answer: A collateral notice can require a Captive Insurer to make available assets, but the value of assets that can be required is capped at the lower of (1) any amount stated in the notice and (2) the amount calculated under Rule 10.3.2(4), with the asset value determined under Chapter 6. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] To apply that cap, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount depends on the Captive Insurer’s structure and the relevant business segment. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] For the Rule 10.3.2(4) limb of the “lower of” test: - For a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, the amount is the sum of (i) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell and (ii) the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] - For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, the amount is the sum of (i) the Captive Insurer’s Insurance Liabilities and (ii) the Captive Insurer’s minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] Accordingly, the collateral notice cannot require assets (valued under Chapter 6) above whichever is lower: the notice-stated amount (if any) or the applicable Rule 10.3.2(4) calculation for the relevant case. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]

question: If the Regulator sends a collateral notice to a Captive Insurer, what is the limit on how much asset value can be required, and how do you work out that limit for a Long-Term Insurance Fund using the Rule 10.3.2(4) calculation?
gold_answer: A collateral notice can require a Captive Insurer to make assets available, but the required asset value (as valued under Chapter 6) is limited to the lower of (i) any amount written into the notice and (ii) the amount calculated under Rule 10.3.2(4). [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] This means you must compute the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount for the relevant case and then compare it to any figure specified in the notice to identify the binding cap. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] For a Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount is calculated as the sum of two components, subject to the stated cross-references in that rule: (1) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund and (2) the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] Once that sum is determined, it becomes the Rule 10.3.2(4) comparator in the “lower of” test used to cap the collateral notice requirement. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] In practice, the maximum asset value that can be required is whichever is lower: the notice amount (if any) or the Long-Term Insurance Fund sum described above. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]

question: If an Authorised Person needs controls to stop fraud and other Financial Crimes and to report suspected cases, what best-practice features should it consider adding to those controls because Financial Crime keeps changing?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person is required to set up and keep effective systems and controls that do two things: help deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and support reporting suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] When putting those systems and controls in place, the Authorised Person should also follow best practices, specifically because Financial Crime is evolving and controls should be designed with that changing threat in mind. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] In other words, the required fraud/Financial Crime controls should not be static; they should be built and maintained in a way that supports prevention/deterrence and reporting while using practical techniques that are identified as best-practice examples. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] The examples given of such best-practice techniques are incorporating secure authentication, using biometrics, and monitoring customer behaviour metrics as part of anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Using these features helps align the way the controls are established with the obligation to maintain effective controls for both stopping suspected misconduct and reporting it. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]

question: When an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using one or more of the credit risk mitigation methods listed for this Section, what policy documentation is required specifically in relation to using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, and how does that documentation obligation relate to the discretionary nature of those exposure reductions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that elects to reduce the value of its Exposures using the credit risk mitigation recognition options in this Section must also have documented policy coverage for its use of any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] This documentation requirement applies in addition to (and is not replaced by) the fact that the Section allows the Authorised Person, at its discretion, to reduce Exposure values using one or more specified methods. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] In practice, this means: - The Authorised Person may choose whether to reduce Exposures and may do so via specific provisions, netting (if Section 4.13 conditions are met), eligible Collateral (meeting Section 4.13 requirements), eligible guarantees (as permitted under Section 4.13.9), qualifying Credit Derivatives (included in Rule 4.13.11 and meeting that Section’s conditions), or securitisation transfers (if Section 4.14 conditions are met). [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] - Separately, it must document its policy for using any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, so that any reliance on those exclusions is governed by an established internal policy. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] Accordingly, discretion to apply the listed reduction techniques does not remove the need for a documented exclusions policy where Rule 4.15.12 exclusions are used. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information, how should it handle material economic assumptions it considers commercially sensitive, and what additional disclosure is required about the Production Target—particularly in light of the caution about when it is difficult to justify commercial sensitivity?
gold_answer: In a Rule 11.9.1 disclosure containing forecast financial information, a Mining Reporting Entity must provide all material economic assumptions it used, and it must also disclose any other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity treats the material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, it still must include a clear statement that it considers them commercially sensitive and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] That sensitivity position should be taken carefully: it is specifically cautioned that where the Mining Reporting Entity has not yet entered into commercially sensitive contracts underpinning assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to conclude that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] Separately from assumptions, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all information required for that Production Target (including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.2.2 and would otherwise be required to notify Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days of its intent to use the passporting procedures, in what circumstances must the Regulator refrain from transmitting the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), and how does that affect the downstream steps tied to Host Regulator confirmation and completion of registration on the Register of Passported Funds?
gold_answer: The Regulator is required to withhold transmitting the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) if it forms certain compliance- or objectives-based views, even though the passporting workflow otherwise contemplates a five-Business-Day notification to Host Regulator(s) after receiving the Rule 3.2.2 notice. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] Specifically, the Regulator must not transmit that notice if it considers the Fund Manager or the Public Fund is not complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds to determine that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may not comply in the future. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] It must also refrain where it considers doing so is necessary and appropriate to meet its objectives. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] Because the subsequent steps in the passporting sequence are expressly tied to Host Regulator involvement and confirmation, withholding the Rule 3.2.4(a) notice prevents the Regulator from proceeding along that path: the Regulator’s obligation to provide notice of intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days is framed as part of the process that is “subject to Rule 3.2.5.” [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] Likewise, publication on the Register of Passported Funds and notification to the Fund Manager that registration is complete occur only after confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator that its Register has been updated. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]

question: For purposes of identifying “Inside Information,” how should an Issuer assess whether information would have a “significant effect on the price” of Securities, and how does the “reasonable investor” investment-decision test operate as the decisive condition for that price-effect assessment?
gold_answer: To determine whether information qualifies as “Inside Information,” the Issuer must apply a combined test that links the “significant effect on price” element to what a reasonable investor would use in making investment decisions. “Inside Information” includes information that is not generally available, relates to Securities (and Related Instruments), and would have a significant effect on the price of those Securities if it were generally available. [#SRC:06929b81-60bd-4eba-b32e-0cd4da539c58] The “significant effect on price” limb is assessed using the reasonable-investor decision criterion: information is likely to have a significant effect on price if and only if it is of a kind that a reasonable investor would be likely to use as part of the basis of investment decisions. [#TGT:4fb237d1-ed32-4d0c-8f77-32eb47b7c12a] This aligns with the additional clarification that the relevant information is information a reasonable investor would use as part of the basis of their investment decision. [#SRC:06929b81-60bd-4eba-b32e-0cd4da539c58] Practically, the Issuer should (i) confirm the information is not generally available and relates to Securities (and Related Instruments), and then (ii) evaluate whether a reasonable investor would likely use that type of information in forming an investment decision, because that is the decisive condition for concluding it would be likely to have a significant effect on price. [#SRC:06929b81-60bd-4eba-b32e-0cd4da539c58] [#TGT:4fb237d1-ed32-4d0c-8f77-32eb47b7c12a]

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do more than one Regulated Activity, what fee do they pay each year for supervision (including the extra charge for each added activity), and what are the deadlines for paying the first year’s fee versus later years’ fees?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person has a Financial Service Permission that covers multiple Regulated Activities, the annual supervision fee is not simply one flat amount; it is built from two parts. [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6] First, the Authorised Person must pay the highest supervision fee that applies among the Regulated Activities it is permitted to undertake. [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6] Second, for each additional Regulated Activity applied for, there is an extra annual supervision fee, but that extra amount is limited to the lesser of $10,000 or the supervision fee that would apply to that additional Regulated Activity. [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6] After calculating what is due, the payment deadline depends on whether it is the initial annual fee or a later annual fee. The initial annual fee must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days after the date the fee becomes due, and it is prorated for the rest of the calendar year. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] For later years, the annual fee for the period starting 1 January must be paid in advance, in full, to the Regulator by 31 January of that same calendar year. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]

question: For a Mining Reporting Entity concerned about disclosing commercially sensitive ore-reserve-related details (such as pricing or volumes under long term contractual commitments), how should it determine what must be included in an ADGM Prospectus, given the Prospectus content standard and the FSRA’s expectation about this Rule obligation?
gold_answer: In an ADGM Prospectus, the Mining Reporting Entity should treat the Prospectus content standard as the driver for what must be included, even where the information is commercially sensitive, while recognising that the FSRA does not expect disclosure of such sensitive details merely to satisfy the specific ore reserves Rule obligation. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] The Prospectus must include all information an investor would reasonably require and expect to make an informed assessment, which expressly covers the Issuer’s assets and liabilities, financial position, profits and losses, and prospects, as well as the nature of the Securities and the rights and liabilities attached to them. [#TGT:84661a10-aff1-4513-8b63-a9bc2f25e5d9] Practically, this means the entity should (i) identify the ore-reserve-related facts that are necessary for an investor’s informed assessment of the Issuer’s position and prospects and the Securities’ characteristics, and (ii) distinguish those from details that are only commercially sensitive and not needed for that investor-focused assessment. [#TGT:84661a10-aff1-4513-8b63-a9bc2f25e5d9] The FSRA’s guidance highlights that, although sensitive items like pricing or volumes under long term contractual commitments are not expected to be disclosed to meet the ore reserves Rule obligation, the entity must still consider whether such information is required to meet Prospectus disclosure expectations for informed investment decision-making. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is preparing a Prospectus in ADGM and has commercially sensitive information (like pricing or volumes in long term contractual commitments), what test should it use to decide what to put in the Prospectus, and how does that relate to the FSRA’s view on the ore reserves Rule obligation?
gold_answer: The Prospectus should be built around what an investor would reasonably need and expect to see to make an informed assessment, and that investor-focused test is what determines whether any commercially sensitive information must be included. [#TGT:84661a10-aff1-4513-8b63-a9bc2f25e5d9] Specifically, the Prospectus content must be sufficient for an informed assessment of (a) the Issuer’s assets and liabilities, financial position, profits and losses, and prospects, and (b) the nature of the Securities and the rights and liabilities attached to those Securities. [#TGT:84661a10-aff1-4513-8b63-a9bc2f25e5d9] At the same time, the FSRA indicates it does not expect a Mining Reporting Entity to disclose commercially sensitive details (for example, pricing or volumes under long term contractual commitments) just to satisfy the ore reserves Rule obligation. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] However, the FSRA also flags that the entity may still need to consider disclosing such information to meet other disclosure requirements, including where an Issuer is issuing a Prospectus within ADGM and must include all information investors would reasonably require and expect for an informed investment decision. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] So the decision point is whether the sensitive information is necessary for that informed assessment standard, not whether it is sensitive in itself. [#TGT:84661a10-aff1-4513-8b63-a9bc2f25e5d9]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information from a Production Target about either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), when can a later update leave out the Rule 11.9.2 details, and what extra warnings must be added if the Production Target relies on Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A later update can leave out the Rule 11.9.2 details only in the specific situation where the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 and the later update meets all the listed conditions, even if the forecast financial information is being presented in connection with the entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] For the later update to qualify, it must (1) refer back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2, and (2) state that the key assumptions from the first disclosure that support the forecast financial information still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] The later update also needs extra, clearly visible statements in two cases: - If the Production Target is entirely based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the update must include an at least equally prominent and nearby statement about the forecast financial information that matches the statement described in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] - If the Production Target is partly based on an Exploration Target, the update must include an at least equally prominent and nearby statement about the forecast financial information that matches the statement described in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]

question: How does the exclusion in Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) affect an Authorised Person’s duty to take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings of voice and electronic communications under Rule 6.8.1(a), particularly for communications involving Clients or other Persons in relation to a Transaction and made on equipment provided or permitted by the Authorised Person?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s obligation to take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings under Rule 6.8.1(a) applies only to the extent it is not carved out by Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv). [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] In scope, the recording duty covers voice and electronic communications with a Client or with another Person where the communication is in relation to a Transaction, including communications about receiving, executing, or arranging execution of Client orders and passing related instructions. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] It also applies only where the communication is made with, sent from, or received on equipment that the Authorised Person provided to an Employee or contractor, or equipment whose use the Authorised Person has sanctioned or permitted. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] However, the effect of Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) is that conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions are excluded from Rule 6.8.1(a), even if they would otherwise fall within the Transaction/Client-related and equipment-based conditions described above. [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] Accordingly, when assessing whether a particular communication must be recorded and retained, the Authorised Person must evaluate both the communication’s subject matter/equipment nexus and whether the communicator falls within the excluded categories. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]

question: If you’re adding up AT1 Capital, what exactly goes into the total, and do you stop there or do you also have to subtract anything later?
gold_answer: To calculate AT1 Capital, you start by adding up the specific items that count as AT1 Capital elements, and then you adjust that total by applying the deductions that are set out later in the same Section. [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9] The items that go into the initial total are: (a) capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3, and (b) the share premium accounts that relate to those instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] The SOURCE explains that AT1 Capital is the sum of AT1 Capital elements referenced in Rule 3.11.2, but it also warns that this sum is not the final number because it is “subject to” deductions that appear later in the Section. [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9] So, you should treat the eligible instruments and their related share premium accounts as the building blocks of the AT1 Capital sum, and then reduce that amount by the later deductions before treating it as the final AT1 Capital figure. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9]

question: Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how do the restrictions on actions pending calculation and notification apply to specific CET1 Capital-related transactions such as cash dividends, bonus Shares, and redemptions or purchases of its own Shares, and what procedural steps must be completed before those actions may be undertaken?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it is restricted from carrying out certain actions, including distributions connected with CET1 Capital, until it completes specified procedural steps. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] In this context, a “distribution in connection with CET1 Capital” includes, among other items, paying cash dividends, issuing fully or partly paid bonus Shares or other capital instruments, redeeming or purchasing its own Shares or other capital instruments, repaying amounts paid up in connection with capital, and distributing other items that are eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] Accordingly, when the Combined Buffer Requirement is not met, the Authorised Person must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] It must also refrain from undertaking any CET1 Capital distribution (including the specific forms listed above) until it has both calculated that maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] This linkage means that the enumerated CET1-related transactions—such as cash dividends, bonus Shares, and buybacks/redemptions—are treated as restricted “distributions” for the period before calculation and notification are completed. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, can it repay paid-up capital or buy back its own Shares right away, and what must it do first before taking those steps?
gold_answer: No. When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must not make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital until it has completed the required calculation and notification steps. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] The types of actions treated as a CET1 Capital distribution include repaying amounts paid up in connection with capital and redeeming or purchasing the institution’s own Shares or other capital instruments. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] Because those transactions fall within the defined set of CET1 Capital distributions, they are among the actions the Authorised Person must hold off on during the restricted period triggered by failing the Combined Buffer Requirement. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] Before it can undertake those actions, the Authorised Person must calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] It must also ensure it does not undertake the distribution until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] In practical terms, the repayment of paid-up capital and a buyback/redemption of own Shares are treated the same as other CET1-related distributions (such as cash dividends or bonus Shares) for purposes of the “wait until calculation and notification” restriction. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do insurance business (Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal) and it also runs as a Cell Company, what fees does it pay each year, and what part changes when it adds more Cells?
gold_answer: It pays a fixed annual supervision fee for the insurance permission and then pays extra annual supervision fees because it operates as a Cell Company, with the Cell-related portion rising as the number of Cells increases. [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] For the insurance side, an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal must pay the Regulator $50,000 each year, and that $50,000 applies whether it carries on one or both activities. [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] If the same Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, it must also pay an additional $8,000 per year for the Cell Company itself. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] On top of that, it must pay $1,000 per year for each Cell, so adding Cells increases the total by $1,000 per Cell. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] Putting these together, the annual total is $50,000 plus $8,000 plus $1,000 times the number of Cells. [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]

question: If Securities are being offered under an Approved Prospectus, do you always need the Prospectus to be current, and how does that compare to cases the Regulator calls Exempt Securities—like Shares that are less than 10% over 12 months of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange?
gold_answer: If Securities are offered for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus, the Prospectus must be a current Prospectus, unless an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] In addition, the Regulator has identified certain types of Securities as Exempt Securities for the purposes of section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR, including Shares that represent, over a 12-month period, less than 10% of the number of Shares of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange. [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] To apply both texts together, you should (1) confirm whether the planned offer is being made “under an Approved Prospectus,” because that triggers the rule that the Prospectus must be current unless the specified exemptions apply. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Then (2) check whether the Securities fit one of the Regulator’s Exempt Securities categories, such as the under-10%-over-12-months Shares category tied to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange. [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] The compliance outcome depends on both determinations: the “current Prospectus” condition governs offers under an Approved Prospectus unless an applicable exemption is available, while the Exempt Securities list defines transaction types the Regulator treats as exempt for the stated FSMR purpose. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]

question: If a fee is an annual fee and it’s the first time it’s due, how do you work out the reduced (prorated) amount for the rest of the year, and what is the deadline to pay it to the Regulator?
gold_answer: For a first-time annual fee, you must both (1) calculate the reduced amount for the remainder of the calendar year using the required proration basis and (2) pay that prorated amount in full to the Regulator within the required time limit. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] The proration basis is the number of months left until the end of the calendar year, meaning the portion due is determined by counting the remaining months to year-end and using that count to set the prorated fee. [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] After the fee becomes due, the initial annual fee—once prorated for the remainder of the calendar year—must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days from the due date. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] Put together, the compliant approach is to compute the portion due based on remaining months to the calendar year-end and then ensure the full prorated amount is delivered to the Regulator within the twenty-day payment window. [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]

question: If an Authorised Person normally files returns through EPRS at the frequency set in EPRS, but then gets a written notice from the Regulator telling it to file in a different form, manner, or frequency, what should it do next and how long should it keep doing it?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should switch from the normal EPRS-based approach to the approach set out in the Regulator’s written notice, because the notice can require a different form, manner, or frequency than the one otherwise prescribed. [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] Under the normal rule, the Authorised Person must prepare its returns following the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) requirements (including the submission frequency stated in EPRS), and it must submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS. [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] When the Regulator issues a written notice that changes the prescribed form, manner, or frequency, the Authorised Person must keep submitting returns in line with that direction on a continuing basis. [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] It should not assume it can go back to the standard EPRS submission method or EPRS frequency on its own; it may only return to the Rule 2.3.2 approach once the Regulator sends another written notice telling it to do otherwise. [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] In practice, the written notice governs the submission expectations until it is replaced or withdrawn by a later written notice, even though the default framework is to prepare and submit via EPRS. [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, and that disclosure also contains material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, what preparation framework applies and what specific compliance substitution is available in place of Rule 11.2.1(1)?
gold_answer: The disclosure must be prepared in accordance with both a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter requirements, and the Mining Reporting Entity may use a specific substitution pathway for Rule 11.2.1(1) when the disclosure includes material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] In particular, where the Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it is not required to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) so long as it instead complies with Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] This means the general preparation obligation for disclosures covering Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets still applies (i.e., preparation in line with a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter), but the specific Rule 11.2.1(1) requirement is conditionally displaced when the material Non-Equivalent Estimates trigger is met and the four listed Rule 11.7 provisions are followed. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity reports Exploration Results (or similar items like Mineral Resources) and also includes material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, what rules does it have to prepare the disclosure under, and what can it do instead of following Rule 11.2.1(1)?
gold_answer: It must prepare the disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard and under the chapter requirements, and it can replace compliance with Rule 11.2.1(1) with compliance with a specified set of other rules if the disclosure contains material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] If the Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it does not need to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) provided it complies with Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] So, for disclosures that include statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, the baseline preparation framework remains in place (Mining Reporting Standard plus the chapter), but there is a conditional alternative route for the Rule 11.2.1(1) element when the material Non-Equivalent Estimates condition is met. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]

question: For an Authorised Person engaged in regulated activities in relation to Virtual Assets, what is the required form of regulatory capital, and how does the amount framework it must align to relate to the Recognised Investment Exchange capital standard (including the operational-expense and buffer components)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in regulated activities in relation to Virtual Assets must hold regulatory capital in fiat form, and the way it holds capital must be consistent with the capital requirements that a Recognised Investment Exchange must meet. [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d] In practical terms, the relevant Recognised Investment Exchange capital standard is expressed by reference to operational expenses over a defined period and a potential additional buffer. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Specifically, the Recognised Investment Exchange standard requires capital equal to 6 months’ operational expenses, and—unless the Regulator directs otherwise—an additional buffer of up to a further 6 months’ operational expenses. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Therefore, when the Authorised Person applies the “consistent with” requirement, it should frame its capital holding approach by reference to that 6-month operational-expense baseline and the possible additional buffer, while ensuring that the capital it holds is in fiat form. [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d] This linkage matters because the Authorised Person’s capital obligation is explicitly tied to the Recognised Investment Exchange benchmark, but with the added constraint that the capital must be held in fiat. [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d]

question: If an Authorised Person is doing regulated Virtual Asset activities, what kind of money must its regulatory capital be held in, and what does the Recognised Investment Exchange rule say about how much capital is based on operational expenses and any extra buffer?
gold_answer: For regulated activities in relation to Virtual Assets, an Authorised Person’s regulatory capital must be held in fiat form, and it must be held in a way that is consistent with the requirements that a Recognised Investment Exchange must meet. [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d] The Recognised Investment Exchange capital requirement is set by reference to operational expenses over a six-month period, with a possible additional buffer. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Concretely, a Recognised Investment Exchange must hold capital equal to 6 months’ operational expenses, plus—unless the Regulator directs otherwise—an extra buffer amount of up to a further 6 months’ operational expenses. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Putting these together, the Authorised Person should ensure (i) the capital is in fiat, and (ii) its capital approach aligns to the same operational-expense-based structure used for a Recognised Investment Exchange (a 6-month baseline and a potential additional buffer). [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d] This answer depends on both texts because one sets the fiat-form and “consistent with RIE” linkage, while the other provides the operational-expense and buffer components of the RIE standard. [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d] [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]

question: How should a Person assess whether carrying out Price Stabilisation will be treated as non-abusive conduct, and what specific compliance showing is required to rely on that outcome under the cross-referenced provisions?
gold_answer: A Person can treat Price Stabilisation as protected from being characterised as abusive only where the stabilisation is carried out in compliance with the applicable Price Stabilisation Rules and the Person can demonstrate that compliance. [#TGT:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1] In particular, the relevant framework described for Price Stabilisation is MKT 6.2, which sets out the Rules that must be complied with when carrying on Price Stabilisation. [#SRC:6befa69b-50a0-463a-bf02-9fdaa4ed741e] The required compliance showing is that the Person establishes they carried out Price Stabilisation in accordance with MKT 6.2; if that is established, the conduct is treated as not contravening section 92 under the effect described for section 93(3)(b). [#SRC:6befa69b-50a0-463a-bf02-9fdaa4ed741e] This aligns with the broader rule that Behaviour does not amount to Market Abuse where it conforms with the Price Stabilisation Rules, making conformity with those rules the key condition for the non-abuse outcome. [#TGT:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1]

question: When a Listed Entity writes its annual financial report, what does it need to say about using the APP 4 “Corporate Governance Principles” under a “comply or explain” approach, and what extra statement must the Directors add if the standards are not fully followed?
gold_answer: In the annual financial report, the Listed Entity should present its position on the APP 4 best practice standards in a way that follows the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach. [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72] The report must first state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the “Corporate Governance Principles”) have been adopted by the Listed Entity. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If the standards have not been fully adopted or have only been partially adopted, the report must explain the reason for not adopting them fully (or only adopting them partially, as relevant) and must also describe what actions, if any, the Listed Entity has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Beyond the explanation, the annual financial report must include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and that statement must be supported by information and assumptions and may include qualifications if needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Together, these elements are how the report gives effect to “comply or explain” in this context. [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72]

question: For information concerning Financial Instruments (or Accepted Virtual Assets/Accepted Spot Commodities/Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives), how should a compliance team assess whether the “not generally available” limb of Inside Information is met when the information could be obtained through research or analysis by users of a market, and how does that assessment interact with the other elements of the Inside Information test?
gold_answer: To assess whether information meets the “not generally available” limb for Inside Information, you must treat information that market users can obtain through research or analysis (conducted by, or on behalf of, users of a market) as “generally available” to them, meaning it would fail the “not generally available” condition and therefore would not qualify as Inside Information on that basis. [#SRC:5107d7d4-642e-466e-a4c5-17377a88b6af] In the specified instrument scope (Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives), Inside Information requires a combined test: the information must be of a Precise nature, must not be generally available, must relate directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers (or to the instruments themselves), and must be likely to have a significant price effect if it were generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Practically, this means you should first determine whether the information is obtainable by market-user research/analysis; if so, treat it as generally available and stop, because the “not generally available” limb is not met. [#SRC:5107d7d4-642e-466e-a4c5-17377a88b6af] If it is not obtainable that way, then evaluate the remaining elements (precision, nexus to Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments, and likely significant price effect if public) to conclude whether it is Inside Information. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: If a message gives people enough details to decide whether to buy or subscribe to securities, when is it still not treated as an "Offer of Securities"—and how does the Regulator’s power to prescribe Exempt Communications affect whether the section 58(1) ban applies?
gold_answer: Even if a message looks like it could influence an investor’s decision, it will not be treated as an "Offer of Securities" (and so will not trigger the section 58(1) prohibition) if it falls within an exclusion from the definition or is prescribed as an exempt communication. [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310] [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] An "Offer of Securities" is defined as a communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information on the terms of the offer and the securities offered so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe. [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310] However, the definition excludes: (a) communications connected with trading of securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange; (b) communications made to comply with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange; and (c) communications prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication. [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310] Separately, the Regulator has power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe certain communications to be Exempt Communications, and those communications are not subject to the section 58(1) prohibition because they fall outside the definition of an "Offer of Securities" in section 59. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] The practical link is that a communication prescribed as exempt (in Rules) is treated as outside the "Offer of Securities" definition, aligning the definition’s exclusion with the Regulator’s prescribing power and the resulting non-application of section 58(1). [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310] [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f]

question: If a VC Manager doesn’t have to keep the Base Capital Requirement or Expenditure Based Capital Minimum on an ongoing basis, what does it still need to do to show it has enough resources, and what must it tell clients and do each year about audits?
gold_answer: A VC Manager may be exempt from keeping the Base Capital Requirement and the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum on an on-going basis, but it still has to operate in a way that shows it has adequate resources to run its business. [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d] Under Principle 4 Resources, an Authorised Person must maintain and be able to demonstrate adequate resources to conduct and manage its affairs, covering financial and system resources and also adequate and competent human resources. [#TGT:68b818e2-d47f-4969-a001-20a713c5f104] In practical compliance terms for this VC Manager, the exemption does not remove key ongoing duties: it must disclose to its clients that it is exempt from those capital requirements. [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d] It must also submit audited financial statements and audit reports annually (as applicable), which supports its ability to demonstrate its financial position and resources. [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d] Separately, it must be able to meet its liabilities as they fall due and have adequate financial resources to manage its affairs prudently and soundly, which is consistent with maintaining adequate financial resources. [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d] It must also ensure the VC Funds it manages are subject to annual audit requirements. [#SRC:4aff464e-93b6-42de-8c43-8f4ab87a867d]

question: If you are using FSRA Guidance that comes from section 15(2) of FSMR, what does it mean that the Guidance is “non binding,” and where might you find it (inside the Rules as notations or outside the Rules), given it should be read together with FSMR and the Market Rules (MKT)?
gold_answer: When using FSRA Guidance issued under section 15(2) of FSMR, you should understand that it is meant to help explain or indicate how the framework works, but it is not binding in itself. [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f] [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] You also need to know where to look for it, because Guidance can show up in two different places: it may be issued by the Regulator as notations to the Rules, or it may be issued by the Regulator without being incorporated into the Rules. [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] This “where it sits” point links directly to how you should use it, because the Guidance is intended to be read in conjunction with FSMR and the Market Rules (MKT) of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA), so you should cross-check the relevant FSMR and MKT provisions while reviewing the Guidance in whichever form you find it. [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f] In practice, treat the Guidance as supporting material that accompanies the FSMR and MKT texts, whether it is embedded as Rule notations or issued separately. [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f] [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd]

question: If a Financial Instrument is not covered by Rule 3.5.7, when can the Regulator give a waiver for an order, and what extra details apply if the waiver is specifically a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 based on the trading system or a negotiated transaction?
gold_answer: For Financial Instruments not covered by Rule 3.5.7, the Regulator can grant waivers in three main situations: the order is large compared with normal market size, the order is held in an order management facility of the Recognised Investment Exchange while waiting to be disclosed, or the Financial Instrument does not have a liquid market. [#SRC:63e56280-5a41-48fb-a327-25aebcb4834a] If the waiver being sought is instead a waiver from Rule 3.5.1 based on the market model and the type of order or transaction, the request must align to one of the listed system/transaction types, such as a system where the price is taken from a widely published reference price from another venue/most relevant liquid market that Members view as reliable, or a system that formalises negotiated transactions under defined pricing conditions. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] Those negotiated-transaction conditions can include being at/within the current volume weighted spread with a volume cap set by the Regulator, or (for instruments that are not in a liquid market) being within a pre-set percentage of a suitable reference price that the Recognised Investment Exchange sets in advance, or being subject to other conditions like a portfolio-trade leg or a volume weighted average price transaction. [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6] The key linkage is that “large in scale” and “held pending disclosure” are waiver grounds in both texts, but only the Rule 3.5.1 waiver text adds the reference-price and volume-weighted spread/cap mechanics needed to justify a market-model or negotiated-transaction waiver. [#SRC:63e56280-5a41-48fb-a327-25aebcb4834a] [#TGT:aa29640b-f2f9-435b-8e56-31e99fff54e6]

question: If an officer of a Reporting Entity answers “yes” to any of the three Inside Information questions (about trading decisions, Insider Trading exposure, or market perception), what does that mean for whether the information must be Disclosed immediately under Rule 7.2.1, and when could Rule 7.2.2 change the outcome?
gold_answer: A “yes” to any of the three questions is a practical signpost that the information may be Inside Information, but the officer still needs to connect that signpost to the immediate Disclosure outcome under Rule 7.2.1 and check whether an exemption applies. [#TGT:d7ac7a38-0a35-4340-99dd-c4470494cbdc] The three questions focus on whether the information would affect a decision to buy or sell Securities at the current market price, whether trading while it remains undisclosed would feel like it could expose the officer to an Insider Trading action, and whether nondisclosure followed by a price change would feel likely to expose the Listed Entity to adverse comment or market perception from groups such as investors or market commentators. [#TGT:d7ac7a38-0a35-4340-99dd-c4470494cbdc] Where any answer is “yes,” that may indicate the information is Inside Information and, if it does not fall within the exemption to immediate Disclosure in Rule 7.2.2, it may need to be Disclosed immediately under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:e0f04b86-eee0-4f4c-876d-f7c431f2b6a5] So, the “yes” answer points toward immediate Disclosure, while Rule 7.2.2 is the specific factor that can prevent immediate Disclosure even when the indicator is present. [#SRC:e0f04b86-eee0-4f4c-876d-f7c431f2b6a5]

question: This document says it should be read together with FSMR, FSRA Rulebooks, and several FSRA guidance documents. If Guidance is only indicative and not binding, what does that mean for how you use this document, and how do you decide whether it is a notation to the Rules or Guidance that is not incorporated into the Rules?
gold_answer: You should use this document as non-binding, indicative Guidance, and then determine which of the Regulator’s two Guidance categories it falls into so you handle it appropriately in your compliance reading set. [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] The document identifies itself as Guidance issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (“FSMR”) and instructs that it be read in conjunction with FSMR and a defined package of FSRA materials: the relevant Rulebooks, the Guidance & Policies Manual, and specific guidance on digital security offerings (ICOs) and virtual assets, plus guidance on the regulatory framework for private financing platforms. [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537] Because the Regulator recognizes Guidance in two forms—(a) Guidance made and issued as notations to the Rules, and (b) Guidance issued but not incorporated into the Rules—you should check whether this Guidance is presented as a notation to the Rules or instead stands as separate Guidance outside the Rules text. [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] Regardless of which form applies, the document’s own instruction to read it alongside FSMR and the listed FSRA rulebooks and guidance materials tells you the intended interpretive context for using it as indicative input rather than binding requirements. [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537]

question: When the Regulator considers using its written-notice power to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security, what information and documentation does the FSRA expect an Issuer to provide in the specific context of a proposed Digital Security, and how does the FSRA’s approach differ between an Approved Prospectus submission and an Exempt Offer?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is contemplating deeming an investment that is not a Security to be a Security by written notice (and may attach terms and conditions), the FSRA expects the Issuer to supply enough information to show that the proposed Digital Security satisfies the requirements of a “Security” as defined in FSMR, because that is the basis on which the FSRA would decide whether to treat the Digital Security as a Security under its deeming power. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] In an Approved Prospectus scenario, the FSRA relies on the documentation submitted through the Approved Prospectus process to make its determination on whether it will deem the Digital Security a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR. [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] In an Exempt Offer scenario, the FSRA instead reviews the Exempt Offer documentation for the limited purpose of enabling its Section 58(2)(b) determination. [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] Importantly, even though the Regulator can impose terms and conditions when exercising its written-notice powers, the FSRA’s review of Exempt Offer documentation is expressly not undertaken to approve the Exempt Offer itself. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986]

question: If an Issuer is offering a Digital Security and the Regulator might send a written notice to treat an investment as a Security, what documents does the FSRA look at to decide this, and does the FSRA’s review mean the Exempt Offer is approved?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator may use a written notice to treat an investment that is not a Security as a Security (and can set terms and conditions), the FSRA expects the Issuer to provide whatever information is needed to show the proposed Digital Security meets the requirements of a “Security” under FSMR, because that is what supports the FSRA’s decision to deem it a Security. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] If the situation requires an Approved Prospectus to be submitted to the FSRA, the FSRA uses the documents provided in that approval process to decide whether it will deem the Digital Security a Security under Section 58(2)(b). [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] If the situation is an Exempt Offer, the FSRA reviews the Exempt Offer documentation for the purpose of making the same Section 58(2)(b) determination. [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] That Exempt Offer review does not mean the FSRA is approving the Exempt Offer itself, even though the Regulator has broad powers to deem and to set conditions by notice. [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to start doing Digital Securities work connected to Arranging Deals in Investments or Insurance Intermediation, when do they have to pay a fee and when is it fee-free, and what do they need to do with their FSRA Supervision Relationship Manager?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person that is an existing ADGM licenced intermediary or MTF, whether fees apply for Digital Securities work depends on whether the firm needs to change the scope of its existing FSP or can stay within it. [#SRC:e793dc36-32f7-42e0-9421-773cac990928] If the firm is adding Digital Securities activities in relation to a different Regulated Activity, it must submit an application to amend the scope of its existing FSP, and the fees are the ones set out in FEES Rule 3.8. [#SRC:e793dc36-32f7-42e0-9421-773cac990928] If instead the firm will provide Regulated Activities in relation to Digital Securities within the scope of its existing FSP, then no fees apply (subject to the stated cross-references), but the firm is required to discuss the plan with its FSRA Supervision Relationship Manager as early as possible because there may be wider fee or other supervisory implications. [#SRC:e793dc36-32f7-42e0-9421-773cac990928] This applies to Digital Securities work tied to Regulated Activities such as Arranging Deals in Investments and Insurance Intermediation, which are explicitly identified as Regulated Activities. [#TGT:c49ba3cc-f21f-4336-905f-5e4ca3a8e16a]

question: If a Recognised Body hasn’t used its Default Rules but seems like it could, can the Regulator tell it to take action—and what steps and reasons are required first?
gold_answer: Yes, the Regulator can issue a “positive” direction telling the Recognised Body to take action when the Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body could take action. [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3] However, before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator must first consult the Recognised Body involved. [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] After that consultation, the Regulator is not allowed to give the direction unless it is satisfied, based on what comes out of the consultation, that at least one of the specified reasons applies. [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] The acceptable reasons are that not acting would create an undue risk to investors or other market participants, or that the direction is needed in the public interest for the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market, or that the direction is needed to support a proposed/possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS (or a particular use of that power) or Rule 6.5.7(c). [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] So, the Default Rules situation triggers the possibility of a positive direction, but consultation and one of these grounds are required before the Regulator can actually issue it. [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3] [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and has to publish a Prospectus, what can someone do to avoid being treated as breaking section 66(1) because the Prospectus was misleading or left something out?
gold_answer: When an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the offer requirements include publishing a Prospectus, so the question of liability for what the Prospectus says (or omits) can arise in that setting. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] A person can avoid committing a contravention of section 66(1) for misleading or deceptive statements or omissions if they can prove a specific defence based on their process and state of mind. [#TGT:39f7e2de-b1d8-46de-8603-e33e4cf70eaf] To rely on it, the person must show (1) they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances, and (2) after making those enquiries, they believed on reasonable grounds that the Prospectus was not misleading or deceptive. [#TGT:39f7e2de-b1d8-46de-8603-e33e4cf70eaf] In other words, the defence is not automatic just because a Prospectus is required for the offer; it depends on proving both reasonable enquiries and a reasonable belief about the Prospectus’s accuracy and completeness. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] [#TGT:39f7e2de-b1d8-46de-8603-e33e4cf70eaf]

question: If a Relevant Person has to keep CDD/due diligence files, transaction records that let you rebuild a transaction, and suspicious activity notifications/reports for at least six years, can they store them electronically, and what do they need to be able to do if the Regulator asks for them?
gold_answer: Yes. The records that a Relevant Person must maintain (where relevant) for at least six years may be stored in electronic format, as long as the electronic records are readily accessible and the Relevant Person can respond promptly to any request from the Regulator for information. [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618] The record set covered includes, among other items: documents and information gathered for initial and ongoing CDD or due diligence on business partners; customer business relationship records (originals or certified copies) such as business correspondence, transaction records detailed enough to reconstruct individual transactions, and internal findings/analysis where activity appears unusual or suspicious even if no Suspicious Activity/Transaction Report is made; internal notifications of suspicious activity to its MLRO; Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting documents; and relevant communications with the FIU. [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98] The six-year minimum runs from the latest of: when the notification/report was made, when the business relationship ends, or when the Transaction is completed. [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98] So, electronic storage is acceptable, but only if it still allows quick retrieval and prompt production to the Regulator on request. [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618]

question: If a Passported Fund’s Fund Manager becomes aware that a custodian or other material service provider has resigned (or been appointed/removed/replaced) and tells the Regulator within the required timeframe, what does the Regulator have to do next, and how quickly must it do it?
gold_answer: If a material service provider to a Passported Fund (including a custodian) resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced, the Fund Manager (or the governing body or trustee) must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable and, for this listed type of event, no later than seven days after it becomes aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] Once the Regulator receives a notification of the kind described in Rule 6.6.2, the Regulator must then notify the relevant Host Regulator of the changes, and it must do so without undue delay. [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] This means the compliance sequence is: - Identify whether the service-provider change is within the specified events (it is, where the service provider is material, including a custodian). [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] - Ensure the Regulator is notified as soon as practicable and within seven days of awareness for that specified event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] - Expect the Regulator, after receiving the relevant notification, to inform the Host Regulator without undue delay. [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] So the Fund Manager’s deadline is tied to practicability and a seven-day backstop for the listed events, while the Regulator’s onward notification is governed by the “without undue delay” standard. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]

question: Where a Payment Service Provider proposes to change a Framework Contract item that is required to be included in the contract (for example, the Payment Service Provider’s office address and contact details in ADGM), what must the Payment Service Provider provide to the Payment Service User and by when, and how does the “unless otherwise agreed in writing” carve-out for a Payment Service User which is not a Natural Person affect what information is in scope of that change process?
gold_answer: If a Payment Service Provider proposes to change either (i) the existing terms of the Framework Contract or (ii) any of the information that the Framework Contract is required to include, the Payment Service Provider must give the proposed changes to the Payment Service User at least two months before the date the changes are intended to start applying. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The information that can fall within this “information specified” category includes, for example, the Payment Service Provider’s name, its ADGM office address and contact details, and the name of its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details, because those items are listed as required inclusions in a Framework Contract. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The “unless otherwise agreed in writing” concept matters for scoping: where the Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User which is not a Natural Person have agreed in writing to vary the otherwise-required contract information, the set of “information” that is required to be in the Framework Contract (and therefore the set of information whose changes would be captured as changes to required information) is determined by that written agreement. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Regardless of whether the change concerns a contract term or a required information item (as applicable), the two-month advance delivery obligation applies to the proposed change before it takes effect. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

question: When a reconciliation is carried out under Rule 15.9.1 and then reviewed by a suitably senior member of the Authorised Person, what written confirmation is required from the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4, and what does that confirmation need to cover in relation to the reconciliation and its review?
gold_answer: For a reconciliation that is performed under Rule 15.9.1 and therefore must be reviewed by a member of the Authorised Person with adequate seniority, the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 is required to produce a written statement. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] That statement must confirm that the reconciliation has been carried out in line with the requirements of the relevant section (i.e., it is not merely an informal acknowledgement but an explicit confirmation of compliance with the section’s requirements). [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] In practical terms, the reconciliation is within scope when it is one “performed in accordance with Rule 15.9.1,” which triggers the review expectation by an adequately senior member of the Authorised Person. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] Separately, the written statement obligation attaches to the individual identified in Rule 15.9.4 and focuses on confirming that the reconciliation itself was undertaken in accordance with the section’s requirements. [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] The two requirements operate together: the reconciliation must be reviewed by an appropriately senior reviewer, and the specified individual must document, in writing, that the reconciliation was undertaken as required. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30]

question: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, which MIR Chapter 5 rules must be complied with, and how does COBS Rule 17.7.4 affect the application of those MIR notification and information requirements to MTFs using Virtual Assets (including the linkage to paragraph 29 of the Guidance on additional Accepted Virtual Assets)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets is required to comply with specified MIR Chapter 5 requirements, and COBS Rule 17.7.4 clarifies that certain Recognised Investment Exchange-style notification and information requirements apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets as additional requirements. [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Concretely, the MIR Chapter 5 obligations for such an Authorised Person include compliance with Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, but only in the circumstances identified in the listed Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37–41, 43, 45–50, 52–55, and 57–62). [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] In addition, COBS Rule 17.7.4 specifies that certain notification requirements that are applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, also apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), and it characterises these as additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Finally, beyond those COBS-applied requirements, MTFs using Virtual Assets must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those described in paragraph 29 of the Guidance regarding the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: When the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund has been amended or replaced, what must the Fund Manager submit to the Regulator in its notification, and what form and timing constraints apply (including any outer deadline once it becomes aware)?
gold_answer: When the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The notification must be made in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] At a minimum, the notification must include reasonable detail describing the event. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] In addition, where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must be accompanied by a copy of the new Prospectus, so the Regulator receives the updated disclosure document alongside the event description. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] This Prospectus-change trigger is expressly listed as a notifiable material event for a Passported Fund, and the seven-day outer limit applies once the Fund Manager becomes aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] Accordingly, compliance requires both meeting the timing requirement for Passported Fund material events and ensuring the submission package satisfies the minimum content and form requirements for the notification. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]

question: If an Authorised Person is writing or publishing Investment Research and there is a conflict of interest, what do they need to do about the conflict, and how must any disclosure be given to the Client?
gold_answer: For Investment Research, the Authorised Person must have adequate procedures and controls in place, and it must also take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] If the conflict is addressed through a disclosure made under Rule 3.3.23, the disclosure has two key requirements: it must be provided in a durable medium, and it must give enough detail for the Client to make an informed decision about the service in which the conflict arises. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9] Putting these together, the Authorised Person should ensure its Investment Research controls and its conflicts process work in tandem: the conflicts process should surface the conflict and drive prevention/management actions, while any disclosure used should be communicated in the required format and tailored in detail to the nature of the Client. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The disclosure’s detail must be sufficient for that specific Client to understand the conflict in the context of the relevant service and decide whether to proceed. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]

question: If an Offer is made partly to or directed at only Professional Clients and partly through a Private Financing Platform to no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, how should Exempt Offer status be assessed when the Offer falls within more than one prescribed circumstance?
gold_answer: You assess Exempt Offer status by confirming that, although the Offer may fall in whole or in part within more than one prescribed circumstance, all parts of the Offer are covered by at least one prescribed circumstance. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] The prescribed circumstances include an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients, and (other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk) an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Accordingly, it is permissible for one portion of the Offer to rely on the “only Professional Clients” circumstance while another portion relies on the “Private Financing Platform/MTF with up to 200 non-Professional Clients/non-Market Counterparties” circumstance, so long as there is no portion of the Offer that is outside all prescribed circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] This requires mapping each tranche or distribution channel to at least one prescribed circumstance and ensuring the platform-based limb is not used for Debentures or Sukuk. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] If every part is covered, the Offer remains an Exempt Offer despite the overlap. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio using the prescribed methodology, what specific components must be included in the Capital Measure, and how does that Capital Measure relate to the Exposure Measure in the ratio?
gold_answer: In calculating the Leverage Ratio, an Authorised Person must use a Capital Measure that is its Tier 1 Capital, and that Tier 1 Capital must be built up as the sum of two specified components.
