[#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Specifically, Tier 1 capital is determined by adding together Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) and Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital). [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11] The Leverage Ratio itself is then computed by dividing this Capital Measure (i.e., Tier 1 Capital as just described) by the Exposure Measure. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] The Exposure Measure is not a capital component; it is the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures, and it must be calculated under the specified exposure rules referenced for that purpose. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Accordingly, the numerator of the ratio is Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital plus AT1 Capital), while the denominator is the Exposure Measure derived from the Authorised Person’s Exposures. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]

question: When considering whether to withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function on the basis that the person is not fit and proper, what specific factors must the Regulator take into account, and how do those factors connect to the particular Controlled Function and the firm’s markets?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is considering withdrawing an Approval given under section 45 because it considers the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question, it should ground that assessment in the broader set of relevant matters it uses when deciding whether to exercise its power under section 46 of FSMR. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] In practice, this means the fit-and-proper conclusion for the specific Controlled Function should be informed by multiple, case-specific considerations rather than a single indicator. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] In forming its view, the Regulator will have regard to all relevant matters, including: (i) the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person (as referenced in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM); (ii) any offences or findings involving dishonesty, fraud, or a financial crime by the Approved Person; and (iii) whether enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, against the Approved Person by the Regulator or other enforcement agencies. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] It will also consider contextual factors that link directly to the withdrawal decision for the Controlled Function in question, including the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing, the nature and activities of the firm concerned, the markets in which the firm operates, and the severity of the risk the individual poses to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] These factors collectively support whether the person should continue to hold the section 45 Approval for that Controlled Function. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]

question: If the Regulator thinks someone is not fit and proper for a specific Controlled Function and may withdraw their Approval, what kinds of things will it look at (for example, crimes, past enforcement, and the firm’s markets) to reach that decision?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator considers that a person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question, it may withdraw an Approval that was given under section 45. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] To reach that fit-and-proper view for the specific Controlled Function, the Regulator’s approach is to consider all relevant matters it uses when deciding whether to exercise its power under section 46 of FSMR, rather than relying on a single fact in isolation. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] In particular, the Regulator will look at a mix of personal conduct, regulatory history, and role/firm context, including: - the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person (as referenced in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM); [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - whether the Approved Person has committed offences or has findings involving dishonesty, fraud, or a financial crime; [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - whether enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, by the Regulator or other enforcement agencies; [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing, and the nature and activities of the firm concerned, including the markets in which the firm operates; and [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] - how severe the risk is to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] These considerations help the Regulator decide whether the person should continue to hold the section 45 Approval for that Controlled Function. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]

question: When an Authorised Person is determining the amount of minority interests of a Subsidiary that is eligible for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, how does the 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement tied to the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount connect to the way Total Risk Exposure Amount must be calculated (including any specified components and adjustments)?
gold_answer: In determining eligible minority interests for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, the Authorised Person must apply a subtraction mechanism that depends on a 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement calculated by reference to the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount, so the Total Risk Exposure Amount must be computed using the required component-sum approach before it can be used in that 6.0% test. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] Specifically, the eligible amount is derived by taking the minority interests of the Subsidiary and subtracting an amount equal to: (i) a defined CET1 Capital “excess/shortfall” measure for the Subsidiary (CET1 Capital of the Subsidiary minus the lesser of two alternative required CET1 amounts, each built from a 6.0% CET1 requirement plus the Combined Buffer Requirement), multiplied by (ii) the minority-interest percentage of all CET1 instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] To supply the Total Risk Exposure Amount input to the 6.0% requirement referenced in that minority-interest calculation, the Authorised Person must calculate Total Risk Exposure Amount (after taking into account Rule 3.5.8) as the sum of Credit RWA, and the risk exposure amounts associated with Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk (calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5). [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]

question: If an Authorised Person is working out how much of a Subsidiary’s minority interests can count in consolidated CET1 Capital, what do they have to calculate about Total Risk Exposure Amount (what it is made up of), and how is that used in the 6.0% CET1 requirement step in the minority-interest formula?
gold_answer: To determine how much of a Subsidiary’s minority interests can be included in consolidated CET1 Capital, the Authorised Person must use a formula that depends on a 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement based on the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount, so the Total Risk Exposure Amount must be calculated in the prescribed way first. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] The minority-interest amount eligible for inclusion is found by starting with the Subsidiary’s minority interests and subtracting a product: the product is (1) the Subsidiary’s CET1 Capital minus the lesser of two alternative required CET1 amounts (each alternative is the sum of a 6.0% CET1 requirement on Total Risk Exposure Amount and the Combined Buffer Requirement), multiplied by (2) the minority-interest share expressed as a percentage of all CET1 instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] For the Total Risk Exposure Amount used in that 6.0% step, the Authorised Person must calculate Total Risk Exposure Amount (after taking into account Rule 3.5.8) as the sum of: Credit RWA, plus the risk exposure amounts for Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk (calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5). [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]

question: For an Authorised Person exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, when is it not required to calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, and what specific quantitative tests and definitions must be applied to determine that outcome?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract is generally required to calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2, but it is not required to perform that calculation if it meets both exemption conditions stated for when the requirement does not apply. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696] To determine whether the exemption is available, the Authorised Person must apply two quantitative tests that are each measured against Capital Resources (as defined in Chapter 3). [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] First, it must compute its “Foreign Currency business” as the greater of (i) the sum of its gross long positions and (ii) the sum of its gross short positions across all Foreign Currencies, and confirm that this amount does not exceed 100% of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] Second, it must confirm that its overall net open position (as defined in Rule A6.4.4) does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] If either threshold is exceeded, the Authorised Person must proceed to calculate the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement under PRU Rule 5.6.2 for the relevant exposure under the Islamic Contract. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696]

question: For an Authorised Person that is both (i) Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA and (ii) incurring Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, Trading Book), what is the maximum percentage limit that applies in each regime, and how does the applicable capital base differ between the Large Exposures limit and the PSIA Exposure limit (including the financing conditions that change the PSIA percentage)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must apply two distinct percentage caps that are triggered by different exposure concepts and measured against different capital bases. For Large Exposures, the Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book condition) that, after reflecting any eligible CRM, exceed 25% of its Tier 1. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] Separately, when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must ensure its Exposure to a Counterparty (including Connected Counterparty groupings and groups of Closely Related Counterparties) does not exceed specified percentages of its Capital Resources, with the applicable percentage depending on how the exposure is financed. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] In practice: - The Large Exposures cap is 25% and is measured against Tier 1, after eligible CRM is taken into account. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] - The Unrestricted PSIA exposure cap is measured against Capital Resources and is 25% where the exposure is financed by the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] - The Unrestricted PSIA exposure cap increases to 40% where the exposure is financed by an aggregate of the Authorised Person’s own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Accordingly, compliance requires tracking both the Tier 1-based Large Exposures ceiling and the Capital Resources-based PSIA exposure ceilings, applying the correct financing condition for the PSIA limit. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity puts out material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and uses the option that means it does not have to follow Rule 11.2.1(1), what does it need to say in its Summary of Reserves and Resources about earlier Non-Equivalent Estimates that still have not been turned into Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and what extra details are required once three years have passed since the first disclosure under Rule 11.7.4?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it can avoid Rule 11.2.1(1) only by complying with Rules 11.7.2, 11.7.3, 11.7.4, and 11.7.6 instead. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] When it has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates in compliance with Rule 11.7.3 and those estimates have not later been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, the entity must include certain updates in its Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907] Those updates must cover: the steps taken to evaluate the earlier Non-Equivalent Estimates; the status of any further evaluation and/or exploration work needed to verify and disclose them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under the Mining Reporting Standard; and the status of the proposed source of funding for that work (including the funding status tied to Rule 11.7.6(1)(b)). [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907] If more than three years have passed since the first disclosure under Rule 11.7.4 and the estimates still have not been verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, the Summary must also explain why that has not happened and set out the entity’s intention, proposed timetable, and proposed source of funding for completing verification and disclosure. [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907]

question: When a Third Party Provider proposes to change the information that the Governing Contract must contain about communication—specifically the Customer’s right to receive revised terms and other information—what must the Third Party Provider do, and by when, before the change takes effect?
gold_answer: If the Third Party Provider proposes to change information that is required to be included in the Governing Contract—such as the communication-related item describing the Customer’s right to receive revised terms of the Governing Contract and other information in accordance with Rule 20.2.5—this is treated as a proposed change to information that the contract must contain. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In that case, the Third Party Provider must provide the proposed change to the Customer no later than two months before the date the change is intended to take effect. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] This timing obligation applies both where the change is to the existing terms of the Governing Contract and where it is to the specified contractual information that must be included in the contract. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] Accordingly, for a change affecting the contract’s communication section (including the Customer’s stated right to receive revised terms and other information), the compliance action is to deliver the proposed revised information to the Customer at least two months in advance of the effective date. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]

question: If the Regulator thinks it’s in the interests of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market to act, what can it tell a Reporting Entity to do, and what else can it require on top of that (including any conditions it can attach)?
gold_answer: When the Regulator is satisfied that acting is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, it can require a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information or to take other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The TARGET adds two important points about how this can work in practice: first, the Regulator can direct that the specified information be disclosed “to the market,” and second, it can go further than disclosure/steps by imposing additional continuing obligations on the Reporting Entity. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The TARGET also states that these directions or additional continuing obligations can be set “on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator,” meaning the Regulator can decide the conditions attached to what it requires. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The SOURCE supports the same trigger and core scope by explaining that the Regulator’s power arises where it is satisfied the action is in the interest of the ADGM and that it may direct disclosure of specified information or other steps it considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] Putting both passages together, the Regulator can (i) order disclosure (including to the market) or other steps, and (ii) separately impose extra ongoing obligations, with Regulator-set terms and conditions. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]

question: For a Mining Reporting Entity that is considering whether commercially sensitive information (such as pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments) should be disclosed, how should it assess whether that information meets the “would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price” threshold by applying the definition of Inside Information, and what does the SOURCE say about the FSRA’s expectation regarding disclosure of such commercially sensitive information under the ore reserves Rule obligation?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should not assume that commercially sensitive information is automatically required to be disclosed for the ore reserves Rule obligation; the FSRA indicates it does not expect disclosure of commercially sensitive details (for example, pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments) solely to satisfy that specific Rule obligation. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] However, the entity should still evaluate whether the same information could fall within disclosure regimes that turn on price sensitivity, by testing it against the definition of Inside Information and the related “significant effect on price” concept referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] Under the TARGET definition, information is Inside Information only if it is of a precise nature, is not generally available, relates directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers (or to the relevant instruments), and would be likely to have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Practically, the Mining Reporting Entity should: (i) determine whether the pricing/volume terms are “precise” and currently not generally available; (ii) confirm the information relates to the Reporting Entity/Issuer or the Financial Instruments; and (iii) assess whether general availability would likely move the price, aligning with the SOURCE’s reference to disclosure triggers based on significant price effect. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has commercially sensitive contract details (like pricing or volumes in long-term commitments), when does that kind of information count as “Inside Information” for Financial Instruments, and how does that connect to the FSRA’s statement about what it expects for ore reserves disclosures?
gold_answer: Commercially sensitive contract details are not automatically expected to be disclosed just to meet the ore reserves Rule obligation; the FSRA states it does not expect a Mining Reporting Entity to have to reveal commercially sensitive information such as pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments for that purpose. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] Even so, the Mining Reporting Entity should consider whether those details might still need disclosure under other requirements that focus on information likely to affect price, which the SOURCE highlights by pointing to obligations tied to information that would significantly affect the price if generally available. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] The TARGET explains when information is “Inside Information” for Financial Instruments (and certain other instruments): it must be precise, not generally available, relate directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers (or the instruments), and be likely to have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] So, to connect the two passages, the entity should first note the FSRA’s limited expectation for ore reserves disclosure, then separately test the same contract details against the TARGET criteria (precise, non-public, related, and price-significant) to determine whether they meet the Inside Information threshold that aligns with the SOURCE’s price-effect disclosure trigger. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: For a Person seeking one of the listed ADGM green/climate designations, what payments are owed to the Regulator at the application stage and after the designation is granted, including the amount and any proration or calendar-year payment timing?
gold_answer: A Person applying for one of the specified designations must pay a $2,000 application fee to the Regulator at the time of applying, and if the designation is granted, the Person must also pay an annual designation fee of $2,000 to the Regulator, with specific proration and timing rules. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] At the application stage, the $2,000 fee applies when the Person applies for any of these designations: ADGM Green Fund, ADGM Climate Transition Fund, ADGM Green Portfolio, ADGM Climate Transition Portfolio, ADGM Green Bond, or ADGM Sustainability Linked Bond. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] After the initial granting of the designation, the Person must pay an annual designation fee of $2,000 that is prorated for the remainder of the calendar year in which the designation is first granted. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] For each subsequent calendar year commencing 1 January, the annual designation fee is payable in full on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] Accordingly, the fee framework combines an upfront application payment for the listed designation types with an ongoing annual fee once the designation has been granted, including proration in the first year and a fixed January payment deadline in later years. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc]

question: Where an Issuer seeks to rely on the exemption from the section 61 FSMR prohibition for admission of additional Units representing less than 10% over 12 months, what trading venue requirement applies to all Units in the class (including those specified under Rule 3.3.5), and how does that requirement interact with the exemption being subject to Rule 3.3.6?
gold_answer: An Issuer may treat the section 61 FSMR prohibition as inapplicable for the admission to trading of Units that, over a 12‑month period, represent less than 10% of the number of Units of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange, but only because that exemption is expressly conditional on compliance with the requirement in Rule 3.3.6. [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace] In parallel, the venue rule for Exempt Offers in respect of Units requires that all Units in the relevant class of Securities that are admitted to trading—including those Units identified under Rule 3.3.5—must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] Read together, this means the Issuer cannot treat the exemption as a basis to admit Units while allowing any Units in that class (including the Rule 3.3.5 subset) to trade somewhere other than a Recognised Investment Exchange; the class-wide trading location requirement still applies. [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] The exemption’s “subject to Rule 3.3.6” condition operates as an additional gate to using the section 61 carve-out for the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, rather than replacing the obligation that all Units in the class trade on such an exchange. [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is allowed by the FSRA to run a separate MTF/OTF that uses Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, does it still need to run another market, and what standard must that market meet?
gold_answer: Yes. When a Recognised Investment Exchange operates an MTF or an OTF, it must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] This remains true even if the Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, alongside its markets for trading Financial Instruments (including Digital Securities). [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] Put simply, the ability to run a separate venue involving Virtual Assets is an additional capability under the Recognition Order, not a replacement for the requirement to have a Recognition Requirements-compliant market in place when running an MTF or OTF. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] Therefore, the Recognised Investment Exchange should structure its operations so that (1) it can run the separate MTF/OTF/MTF using Virtual Assets where permitted, and (2) it continues to operate a market that meets the Recognition Requirements as required for MTF/OTF operators. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

question: If an Authorised Person takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, the SFT is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, and the firm is using the FCCA, what number should it use instead of E when working out the credit risk weighted exposure—and how can it choose the haircut method when calculating that number for a collateralised transaction that is not an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction?
gold_answer: The firm should use E* (not E) as the exposure figure when it calculates the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the CR Exposure, provided it has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, and it is using the FCCA. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] To get E*, the Authorised Person must follow the calculation approach set out in the referenced App4 rules (A4.3.2 to A4.3.6). [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] When E* is being calculated for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions, the firm must also decide what haircuts to apply using one of two allowed methods. [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Those two options are: (a) standard supervisory haircuts, or (b) own estimate haircuts. [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Putting this together, the firm calculates E* under the App4 framework, applies haircuts using one of the two permitted haircut methods for the relevant type of collateralised transaction, and then substitutes E* for E in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]

question: How should an entity determine whether it must hold an additional capital buffer when it is (i) an Authorised Person to whom the FSRA applies proportionality under COBS Rule 17.3 / MIR Rule 3.2.1 in relation to virtual assets, and (ii) also a Recognised Investment Exchange subject to a baseline capital formula expressed in months of operational expenses? In your answer, explain how the proportionality and risk assessment interacts with the months-of-expenses baseline and the possibility of a Regulator direction.
gold_answer: Where the entity is both an Authorised Person in scope of the FSRA’s proportionality approach for capital buffers and a Recognised Investment Exchange with a months-of-expenses capital baseline, it should treat the Recognised Investment Exchange requirement as establishing a minimum capital amount and then assess whether an additional buffer is required under the proportionality/risk framework. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Specifically, as a Recognised Investment Exchange it must hold capital equal to six months’ operational expenses, and—unless the Regulator directs otherwise—may also be required to hold an additional buffer of up to a further six months’ operational expenses. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Separately, when applying COBS Rule 17.3 / MIR Rule 3.2.1 to an Authorised Person, the FSRA applies proportionality to decide whether any additional capital buffer must be held, considering the size, scope, complexity, and nature of the Authorised Person’s activities and operations, and (if a buffer is needed) the appropriate amount of regulatory capital for that buffer. [#SRC:01e0aad6-805e-4a33-ac77-66a5d6eb6d5a] If the FSRA considers the Authorised Person to be high risk, it may attract higher regulatory capital requirements, which would inform whether the entity should expect a larger buffer beyond the baseline months-of-expenses amount (subject to any Regulator direction affecting the Recognised Investment Exchange buffer). [#SRC:01e0aad6-805e-4a33-ac77-66a5d6eb6d5a] [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]

question: If a firm is both an Authorised Person dealing with virtual assets and a Recognised Investment Exchange, what capital does it need to hold, and when could it need extra capital beyond the 6 months of operational expenses?
gold_answer: A firm that is both an Authorised Person in relation to virtual assets and a Recognised Investment Exchange needs to combine the two capital concepts: the Recognised Investment Exchange sets a months-of-expenses capital floor, and the Authorised Person framework explains when extra buffer capital may be required based on proportionality and risk. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] As a Recognised Investment Exchange, it must hold capital equal to six months’ operational expenses, and—unless the Regulator directs otherwise—there can also be an additional buffer of up to another six months’ operational expenses. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Beyond that baseline, the FSRA applies proportionality when applying COBS Rule 17.3 / MIR Rule 3.2.1 to an Authorised Person, looking at the size, scope, complexity, and nature of the firm’s activities and operations to decide whether any additional capital buffer must be held and, if so, how much regulatory capital is appropriate for that buffer. [#SRC:01e0aad6-805e-4a33-ac77-66a5d6eb6d5a] If the FSRA considers the Authorised Person to be high risk, it may face higher regulatory capital requirements, which is a key trigger for expecting a larger buffer requirement on top of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s months-of-expenses amount (again, noting the Regulator can direct otherwise for the Recognised Investment Exchange buffer). [#SRC:01e0aad6-805e-4a33-ac77-66a5d6eb6d5a] [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]

question: For a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class, how must an Authorised Person determine the applicable risk-weighting when Rule 4.12.5 is not met, given that the table-based risk weights are stated to apply subject to Rule 4.12.5?
gold_answer: If Rule 4.12.5 is not met for a CR Exposure, the CR Exposure must be handled under Rule 4.12.4 rather than being risk weighted using the central government and central bank asset class table. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] This conclusion applies even where the exposure falls within the central government and central bank asset class, because the table-based approach is expressly conditional on Rule 4.12.5 being satisfied. [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] In other words, the table (with risk weights by Credit Quality Grade, including 0% for Grade 1, 20% for Grade 2, 50% for Grade 3, 100% for Grades 4 and 5, 150% for Grade 6, and 100% for Unrated) is the method an Authorised Person must use only when Rule 4.12.5 applies. [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] Where the Rule 4.12.5 condition is not met, the required treatment is to follow Rule 4.12.4 for that CR Exposure, instead of applying any of those table risk weights. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] The practical compliance step is therefore to first assess whether Rule 4.12.5 is met; if it is not, the exposure is routed to Rule 4.12.4 rather than the table. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]

question: If you have a CR Exposure that sits in the central government and central bank asset class, what should you do if Rule 4.12.5 is not met—do you still use the table risk weights (like 0% for Credit Quality Grade 1 and 100% for Unrated), or do you follow a different rule?
gold_answer: You should not use the central government and central bank asset class table when Rule 4.12.5 is not met; instead, the CR Exposure must be treated under Rule 4.12.4. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] The table method is only the required approach for an Authorised Person when risk weighting a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class if the conditions tied to Rule 4.12.5 are satisfied, because the table is stated to apply subject to Rule 4.12.5. [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] That means the listed risk weights—such as 0% for Credit Quality Grade 1, 20% for Grade 2, 50% for Grade 3, 100% for Grades 4 and 5, 150% for Grade 6, and 100% for Unrated—are not the fallback when Rule 4.12.5 fails. [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] Instead, the fallback is explicitly to apply the treatment required by Rule 4.12.4 for that CR Exposure. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] Operationally, you first check whether Rule 4.12.5 is met; if it is not, you route the exposure to Rule 4.12.4 rather than selecting a risk weight from the table. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]

question: When an Authorised Person is assessing a guarantee as credit risk mitigation (CRM), how do the eligibility conditions for recognising the guarantee’s effects interact with the risk-weight treatment for CR Exposures to specified multilateral development bank (MDB) institutions, and which named institutions receive the stated risk weight?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person can only recognise the effects of CRM from a guarantee if the guarantor falls within the permitted set of provider types, including an MDB referred to in Rule 4.12.8 (as well as other listed categories such as central governments/central banks, PSEs, qualifying banks and Securities firms, or certain externally rated entities). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] Separately, for the MDB asset class treatment described, the Authorised Person is required to apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to each of the specifically named institutions: the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, and the European Commission. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] Putting these together for compliance analysis, the guarantee-recognition step depends on whether the guarantor is an eligible provider type (which can include an MDB), while the risk-weight step in the MDB asset class provision is triggered by the exposure being to one of the four named institutions and mandates a 0% risk weight for that CR Exposure. [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count a guarantee as CRM, who can provide it, and how does that sit alongside the rule that gives a 0% risk weight for CR Exposures to certain named MDB institutions?
gold_answer: To treat a guarantee as effective CRM, an Authorised Person must first check that the guarantee provider is within the allowed categories, which include central government or a central bank, an MDB referred to in Rule 4.12.8, International Organisations referred to in Rule 4.12.9, a PSE, qualifying banks and Securities firms, or another entity with an external credit assessment mapping to Credit Quality Grade 3 or better. [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] In addition to that eligibility screen for recognising the guarantee’s CRM effects, there is a separate MDB asset class requirement that sets the risk-weight outcome for certain exposures: the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, or the European Commission. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] In practical terms, the CRM recognition question is about whether the guarantor is an eligible type (including an MDB category), while the 0% risk weight rule is about whether the CR Exposure is to one of those four named institutions and then mandates the 0% treatment for that exposure. [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]

question: If the Regulator gets the Rule 3.1.2 notice and would normally tell Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days that it plans to use the passporting procedures, when is it not allowed to send the notice under Rule 3.1.4(a), and what does it have to do after Host Regulator(s) confirm their register is updated?
gold_answer: The Regulator must not transmit a notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it thinks the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds to decide the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may not comply in the future. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] It also must not transmit that notice if it considers it necessary and appropriate to hold back in order to further one or more of its objectives. [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] If those reasons to hold back do not apply and the process goes ahead, then within five Business Days after receiving the notice mentioned in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator has to send Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) a notice that it intends to use the passporting procedures, for places where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] Once the Host Regulator(s) confirm their Register of Passported Funds has been updated with the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must promptly publish those details on the Register of Passported Funds and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: If an SCSF has procedures to spot and handle a Member (or participant) who does not settle, does one failed trade automatically mean it has not met the standard FSRA looks at under MIR Rule 4.3.3, given the rule about a Recognised Clearing House and a specific transaction not settling?
gold_answer: A single failed trade does not, on its own, determine whether the SCSF meets what FSRA looks for under MIR Rule 4.3.3, because the assessment is about whether the SCSF has satisfactory arrangements to support timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] FSRA may consider whether the SCSF has practical measures in place such as rules and practices for clearing and settlement (including any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), processes to match trades and confirm the parties agree on trade details, and arrangements for deliveries and payments in all relevant jurisdictions. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] FSRA may also look at how the SCSF detects and deals with a Member (or participant) failing to settle, what action it can take to settle a trade when a Member (or participant) does not, how it monitors Members’ settlement performance, and whether it has Default Rules and default procedures. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731] This arrangements-based approach is consistent with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as failing its Recognition Requirement merely because it cannot arrange settlement for a specific transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] So, the compliance question is whether the SCSF’s overall framework exists and functions to manage settlement and defaults, not whether every individual transaction always settles. [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731][#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

question: When the Regulator requests information from a Representative Office that the Representative Office or another member of its Group has already provided to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, how may that information be used in the Regulator’s oversight, and where are further Rules and Guidance identified for obtaining information from the Representative Office’s lead regulator?
gold_answer: When the Regulator asks for information that a Representative Office (or another member of its Group) has already given to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, the Representative Office is required to provide that information to the Regulator. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] Once obtained, the information may be considered by the Regulator in two linked oversight contexts: it may be taken into account as part of the fit and proper test referenced in Chapter 2, and it may also be used in the supervision of the firm (including in a group supervision context). [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] In addition, where the compliance question involves obtaining information specifically from a Representative Office’s lead regulator (which can be relevant when the information has already been shared with external regulators), the text points to a dedicated location for additional requirements: further Rules and Guidance on obtaining such information are set out in GEN 9.15.3. [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] Taken together, the obligation is to furnish the requested previously-shared information, and the regulatory consequence is that the Regulator may use it for fit and proper assessment and ongoing supervision, with GEN 9.15.3 identified as the place to look for more detail on lead-regulator information gathering. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050]

question: If the Regulator asks a Representative Office for information that the Representative Office (or another Group member) already gave to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, what does the Representative Office have to do, and what can the Regulator use that information for (including where to find extra guidance about the lead regulator)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator requests it, the Representative Office must give the Regulator the information that it or another member of its Group has already provided to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] The same information is not just collected for its own sake: it may be taken into account by the Regulator as part of the fit and proper test described in Chapter 2, and it may also be used in the supervision of the firm, which sits within the stated group supervision context. [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] If you need to know where the rulebook points you for more detail on getting information from a Representative Office’s lead regulator (a related channel for obtaining regulatory information), the text identifies GEN 9.15.3 as the place where further Rules and Guidance are set out. [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050] So the practical compliance outcome is: provide the requested previously-shared information to the Regulator, and understand it can feed into both fit-and-proper assessment and ongoing supervisory work, with GEN 9.15.3 flagged for additional lead-regulator information-gathering guidance. [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003] [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050]

question: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, how may the Customer and the Third Party Provider contractually adjust the application of specific Rules, and how does that interact with the Third Party Provider’s liability to its Customer for charges and interest arising from non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Third Party Transaction?
gold_answer: For a Customer that is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider can, by written agreement, disapply a defined set of Rules and can also agree a different time period for certain unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction matters; however, the Third Party Provider still bears liability to its Customer for specified financial consequences when it fails to execute, or executes defectively or late, a Third Party Transaction. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Specifically, the written agreement mechanism is limited to the Rules listed (including those on charges for information, withdrawal of consent, revocation of a Payment Order, requests for refund, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for charges), and it also permits the parties to set a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Separately, the Third Party Provider is liable to its Customer for any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest the Customer must pay when the Third Party Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Third Party Transaction causes those amounts. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] In practice, any written disapplication of the listed Rules should be assessed against this liability outcome, because the liability statement focuses on the consequence of execution failures (charges and interest) rather than on whether particular Rules have been switched off. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151]

question: If someone is trying to comply with a requirement under this Part, what kinds of false information are they not allowed to give, and what other actions (like blocking an investigation) are treated as non-compliance with examples?
gold_answer: When a person is acting in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under this Part, they must not give information that is false or misleading in a material way if they know it is false or misleading, and they must not do so recklessly either. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] The non-compliance discussion describes this same type of behavior as a contravention where a person deliberately or recklessly provides materially false or misleading information in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] It also explains that non-compliance can occur even without false statements: conduct intended to obstruct us in using our investigative powers is also treated as a contravention. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] The examples given of obstruction include not showing up at a specified time and place to answer questions, hiding or destroying documents, not providing information or documents specified by us, refusing access to premises, and not giving assistance connected to an investigation. [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23] So, the rule focuses on knowingly or recklessly giving materially false or misleading information in supposed compliance, and the non-compliance discussion adds that actively getting in the way of an investigation is also covered, with concrete examples of what that looks like. [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]

question: When an Authorised Person is identifying which capital instruments can be included in its Available Stable Funding (ASF), how should it treat instruments that qualify as AT1 Capital, including any related Share premium accounts, given the ASF eligibility cross-references and the stated exclusion for certain Tier 2 instruments?
gold_answer: In identifying capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding (ASF), an Authorised Person must base its selection on whether the relevant capital elements meet the eligibility requirements under Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2, while also applying the explicit exclusion for Tier 2 capital instruments that have a residual maturity of less than one year. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] Where the capital element under consideration is AT1 Capital, the composition of AT1 Capital is limited to (i) capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3 and (ii) the Share premium accounts that relate to those eligible instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] Practically, this means the Authorised Person should first determine whether the item is an AT1-eligible instrument under Rule 3.11.3 and identify any associated Share premium accounts, and then assess whether those capital elements fall within the categories of capital elements that are eligible for ASF inclusion by reference to the ASF cross-referenced rules. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1] The Tier 2 residual-maturity exclusion applies specifically to Tier 2 instruments and therefore does not describe an exclusion for AT1 elements as such; however, the Authorised Person must still apply that Tier 2 filter when any Tier 2 instruments are being considered for ASF. [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]

question: When a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity has no Exploration activities in a quarter but does have production and development expenditure and tenement changes, what statements and tenement/expenditure details must still be included in the quarterly report, and what is the latest disclosure deadline after the quarter ends?
gold_answer: Even if there are no Exploration activities in the quarter, the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity must still produce a quarterly report containing the required categories of information (including explicit “no activity” statements where applicable) and disclose it within the required timeframe. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] The disclosure deadline is no later than one month after the end of the quarter for the report required by Rule 11.10.1. [#SRC:8e80c422-3b41-4546-b511-41bb90ad9e79] On content, the report must include a statement that there have been no activities relating to Exploration where that is the case. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] It must also include details of production and development activities (or a statement of none, if applicable) and a summary of expenditure incurred relating to both Exploration activities and production/development (so production/development expenditure must be summarized even if Exploration activity is absent). [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] The report must further cover Mining Tenements held at quarter end (location and percentage interest held, including beneficial interests in farm‑in/farm‑out agreements) and Mining Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including those beneficial interests) and their location. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] Where applicable, these disclosures are made for the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis. [#TGT:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22]

question: For a Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund that is exempt from many detailed requirements, what core obligations still apply when managing the Fund, and how do those obligations connect to the overarching obligations referenced for such Fund Managers (including Rule 12.2, GEN Section 2.2, and GEN Chapter 3)?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund remains subject to key, overarching Fund Manager obligations even though it is exempt from many detailed requirements that apply to Public Funds and Exempt Funds. [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e] In practice, when managing the Fund (including the Fund Property), the Fund Manager must operate in line with the Fund’s Constitution and the most recent Prospectus, carry out the functions assigned to it by the Constitution and by or under the Rules, and comply with conditions or restrictions imposed by the Regulator (including those attached to its Financial Services Permission or relating to the Fund). [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b] These concrete management and compliance duties sit within the broader framework the Fund Manager must still observe for a Qualified Investor Fund—namely the general duties and functions in Rule 12.2, the Principles for Authorised Persons in GEN Section 2.2, and the management, systems and controls expectations in GEN Chapter 3. [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e] The Fund Manager must also comply with requirements or limitations under the Rules, including limits on financial interests it or its associates may hold in a Fund for which it is the appointed Fund Manager. [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b]

question: If you’re a Fund Manager of a Qualified Investor Fund and you don’t have to follow many of the detailed rules for Public Funds and Exempt Funds, what do you still have to do day-to-day when running the Fund, and which big “overarching obligations” are you still expected to follow (Rule 12.2, GEN 2.2, and GEN Chapter 3)?
gold_answer: Even for a Qualified Investor Fund, the Fund Manager is not “rule-free”: it stays subject to most of the main, overarching obligations that apply to Fund Managers, despite being exempt from many detailed requirements that apply to Public Funds and Exempt Funds. [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e] Day-to-day, that means the Fund Manager must manage the Fund and the Fund Property according to the Fund’s Constitution and the latest Prospectus, and it must carry out the functions given to it by the Constitution and by or under the Rules. [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b] It also has to follow any conditions or restrictions the Regulator imposes, including those tied to its Financial Services Permission or imposed in respect of the Fund. [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b] Those specific duties connect back to the overarching obligations the Fund Manager must still keep in mind for a Qualified Investor Fund: Rule 12.2 on general duties and functions, GEN Section 2.2 on the Principles for Authorised Persons, and GEN Chapter 3 on management, systems and controls. [#SRC:8258f9f2-c4ef-42b0-9226-99d2db70344e] Finally, it must comply with requirements and limitations under the Rules, including limits on financial interests it or its associates may hold in a Fund where it is the appointed Fund Manager. [#TGT:6923614c-bd88-4a42-bd39-8c07e66d302b]

question: If an Applicant/Authorised Person is doing both conventional assets and Virtual Assets and needs FSRA approval for both, can they avoid paying two sets of fees, and when can the Regulator cut, waive, or give back fees (including late fees)?
gold_answer: An Applicant/Authorised Person that will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets needs to seek FSRA approval to carry out its Regulated Activity for both asset types. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] Whether the fees for the conventional and Virtual Asset-related activities end up being cumulative is not presented as automatic; instead, the FSRA indicates that fees attributable to that Authorised Person may not be cumulative if the FSRA uses its discretion to reduce or waive a fee. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] Separately, the Regulator has an explicit power to provide fee relief: it may at any time reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee, and this includes any supplementary fee or late payment fee, if it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Putting these together, a firm should plan for fees linked to approvals for both asset types, but can ask for non-cumulative treatment or other relief by pointing to case-specific fairness and reasonableness considerations, recognizing the decision is discretionary. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] The FSRA also recommends discussing fee questions with it as early as practicable to address how fees may be handled in the firm’s situation. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689]

question: When an Issuer is preparing an Offer of Digital Securities and wants the Regulator to treat an investment that is not otherwise a Security as a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and Rules, what role does the FSRA expect the Issuer’s legal advisers to play, and how does the Regulator effect that treatment (including the form of action and any conditions)?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Issuer should use suitable legal advisers to support compliance across the Offer process, including helping the Issuer obtain the FSRA’s treatment of the Digital Security as a Security under the relevant framework, and to manage the Offer documentation process with the FSRA. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The Regulator effects the treatment of an investment that is not a Security as a Security by issuing a written notice deeming it to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may attach whatever terms and conditions it considers appropriate to that deeming. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Practically, the FSRA expects legal advisers to assist the Issuer in ensuring compliance with the applicable provisions of FSMR and MKT (including the Listing Rules within MKT), and to support the drafting of Offer documentation that will be reviewed by the FSRA. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The FSRA also generally expects to engage directly with the Issuer’s legal advisers throughout the process, particularly around drafting and FSRA review of the Offer documentation, which aligns with the need to address any terms and conditions the Regulator may impose in its written notice. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: If an Issuer is doing an Offer of Digital Securities and needs the Regulator to treat something that is not a Security as a Security, what should the Issuer’s legal advisers help with, and how does the Regulator make that decision (and can it add conditions)?
gold_answer: The Issuer should consider appointing legal advisers with the right skills and experience to support the Issuer through the Offer process, including helping the Issuer meet the relevant requirements and navigate the steps needed for the FSRA to treat a Digital Security as a Security under the applicable framework. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The Regulator makes that treatment decision by sending a written notice that deems an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] The written notice can be subject to terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate, so the Issuer should be prepared to address those conditions as part of its overall Offer planning. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] In addition, the FSRA expects legal advisers to help ensure the Issuer’s compliance with the applicable provisions of FSMR and MKT, including matters connected to the Listing Rules within MKT. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The FSRA also generally expects direct engagement with the Issuer’s legal advisers, especially on drafting and FSRA review of the Offer documentation, which is where the deeming approach and any conditions would typically need to be reflected clearly. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: When an Authorised Person is acting as a Virtual Asset Custodian and applying the custody requirements in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6 together with the additional Rules in COBS Rule 17.8, how must the terms “Client Investments” and “Investments” be interpreted in relation to Virtual Assets, and what is the stated regulatory purpose for that interpretive approach?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person providing custody of virtual assets as a Virtual Asset Custodian must apply the custody framework in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6 and also comply with the additional requirements in COBS Rule 17.8. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] In doing so, the interpretive rule for Rule 17.8.1 requires that “Investment” or “Investments” (and therefore the related references to “Client Investments”) be treated as including “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable. [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] This means that, for the purposes of applying the custody obligations that operate by reference to “Client Investments,” Virtual Assets are brought within that same terminology rather than being treated as outside the scope of those references. [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] The stated regulatory purpose for this approach is to ensure that Accepted Virtual Assets receive the same protections as other similar products and activities under FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7]

question: If a firm is a Virtual Asset Custodian, what does Rule 17.8.1 mean for how you read “Investments” and “Client Investments” in the custody rules, and why did the FSRA choose to treat Virtual Assets that way?
gold_answer: If the firm is acting as a Virtual Asset Custodian, it must meet the custody requirements in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6 and also follow the extra requirements in COBS Rule 17.8. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] For the specific purpose of Rule 17.8.1, the words “Investment” or “Investments” must be understood to include “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” and this automatically carries through to the related term “Client Investments.” [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] Practically, when you apply any custody obligation that refers to “Client Investments,” you should treat Virtual Assets as falling within that label rather than as a separate category outside the definition. [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] The FSRA explains that this interpretive approach is intended to make sure Accepted Virtual Assets get the same protections as other similar products and activities under FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7]

question: Where a Fund Manager enters into a Delegation Agreement or Outsourcing Agreement under the Fund Rules, which text governs the applicable requirements: the chapter that states it does not apply to Fund Managers, or Appendix A1 (APP 1); and what core agreement and record-keeping provisions must the Fund Manager (and, if appointed, the Trustee) ensure are included and maintained, noting any stated carve-out for a Qualified Investor Fund?
gold_answer: For a Fund Manager, the chapter that expressly excludes Fund Managers is not the governing text; instead, the Fund Manager is directed to the provisions in section 15.3 and Appendix A1.3 of the Fund Rules, so the operative requirements for delegation/outsourcing sit in APP 1 rather than that chapter. [#SRC:77d6d088-e887-4010-b1f2-c066a0409cca] APP 1 applies to a Fund Manager and, if appointed, the Trustee for every Delegation Agreement and Outsourcing Agreement made under the Rules, but it is stated not to apply to a Qualified Investor Fund. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] Within that scope, the Fund Manager/Trustee must ensure the relevant agreement describes the functions/activities and service standards, and prevents the Service Provider from further delegation/outsourcing without prior approval from the Fund Manager/Trustee (as applicable). [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] The agreement must also require the Service Provider to keep transaction records that support preparation of compliant accounts, retain those records for at least six years, keep them open to inspection by the Regulator, the Fund’s Auditor and any oversight function provider, and be able to reproduce them in English hard copy within no more than three days if the Regulator requests. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] Separately, the Fund Manager/Trustee must keep records of all agreements and instructions to the Service Provider for at least six years. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b]

question: If a Fund Manager is looking at a chapter that says it does not apply to Fund Managers, but the Fund Manager is also entering into a Delegation Agreement or Outsourcing Agreement, which part should they follow instead, and what are the main things the agreement must cover (including how long records must be kept and how fast they must be reproduced if the Regulator asks), and does this change for a Qualified Investor Fund?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager should not treat the excluded chapter as the source of its requirements, because that chapter says it does not apply to Fund Managers and points Fund Managers to section 15.3 and Appendix A1.3 of the Fund Rules. [#SRC:77d6d088-e887-4010-b1f2-c066a0409cca] For delegation and outsourcing, APP 1 is the relevant text because it applies to a Fund Manager and, if appointed, the Trustee for every Delegation Agreement and Outsourcing Agreement made under the Rules, while also stating that APP 1 does not apply to a Qualified Investor Fund. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] Under APP 1, the Fund Manager/Trustee must ensure the agreement spells out what functions or activities are being performed and what service standards apply, and it must stop the Service Provider from passing the work on again (delegating or outsourcing) unless the Fund Manager/Trustee gives prior approval. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] The agreement must require the Service Provider to keep records explaining transactions for each activity/function, keep them in a way that supports preparing accounts under the Rules, retain them for at least six years, and make them available for inspection by the Regulator, the Fund’s Auditor and any oversight function provider. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] If the Regulator requests copies, the records must be reproducible within a reasonable time not exceeding three days, in English and hard copy. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b]

question: If an Authorised Person is a Virtual Asset Custodian and also uses Third Party Agents for Client Accounts, how often does it need to do reconciliations and send statements, and what exactly is being checked each time?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person has to meet separate minimum frequencies depending on whether it is dealing with Accepted Virtual Assets under custody or Safe Custody Assets/Client Accounts (including those with Third Party Agents). [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32] For Accepted Virtual Assets it holds under custody for Clients, it must perform reconciliations of a Client’s Accepted Virtual Asset holdings at least every week, and it must send statements of a Retail Client’s Accepted Virtual Assets holdings at least monthly. [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32] For Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents, it must at least every calendar month compare (reconcile) its own records of those Client Accounts to the monthly statements it receives from the Third Party Agents. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] It also has two six‑monthly checks: it must count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person or its Nominee Company and reconcile the count to its records, and it must reconcile each Client’s ledger balance to the Authorised Person’s records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange wants to run an MTF using Virtual Assets, what has to be written into its Recognition Order, what rules apply to the MTF versus the rest of its business, and what extra market does it have to run at the same time?
gold_answer: To run an MTF using Virtual Assets, a Recognised Investment Exchange needs its Recognition Order to include a stipulation that permits it to operate an MTF. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] Once that permission is in place, the Recognised Investment Exchange must follow the Virtual Asset Framework for the part of its activity that is the operation of the MTF using Virtual Assets, but it must keep the rest of its operations compliant with the MIR Rules. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] Separately, whenever a Recognised Investment Exchange is operating an MTF (regardless of whether it is using Virtual Assets), it must also operate a market that meets the Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] Putting these points together: the Recognition Order stipulation is the gateway to operating the MTF, the Virtual Asset Framework governs the MTF’s Virtual Asset operation, the MIR Rules govern the remainder of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s operations, and operating the MTF triggers the additional obligation to operate a Recognition Requirements-compliant market at the same time. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

question: For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, what systems-and-controls capability is required to support compliance with the “at all times” capital standard, and what immediate notification duty is triggered if those controls indicate the firm cannot currently meet, or is unlikely to meet in future, the relevant capital rule?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must be able to maintain and evidence continuous compliance with its capital standard by combining (i) an “at all times” capital threshold and (ii) systems and controls that let it verify and demonstrate its position. Specifically, a Domestic Firm must hold Capital Resources that are at least equal to its Capital Requirement at all times. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] To support that continuous requirement, the Authorised Person must have appropriate systems and controls designed to ensure it can be certain it has adequate Capital Resources to meet the capital adequacy requirements at all times and to enable it to demonstrate its capital position at any particular time if the Regulator requires. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] If, through operating those systems and controls, the Authorised Person concludes that it does not currently satisfy, or is not likely to be able to satisfy in future, the requirements of Rule 3.2.3, it must immediately inform the Regulator in accordance with Rule 3.2.5. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] In practice, this means the firm’s monitoring and reporting framework should be capable of identifying any shortfall (or expected shortfall) against the Capital Resources ≥ Capital Requirement standard and triggering immediate regulatory notification when that conclusion is reached. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79]

question: If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm, what does it need to do to make sure it always has enough capital, and what should it do right away if its own monitoring shows it can’t meet (or probably won’t meet) the capital rule?
gold_answer: A Domestic Firm must continuously meet a minimum capital position and have internal arrangements that let it check and prove that position. The baseline requirement is that an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must, at all times, have Capital Resources that are at least equal to its Capital Requirement. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] To manage that “at all times” standard, the Authorised Person is required to maintain appropriate systems and controls so it can be certain it has adequate Capital Resources to meet the capital adequacy requirements at all times and so it can demonstrate its capital position at any particular time if the Regulator asks. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] If those systems and controls lead the Authorised Person to the view that it does not currently satisfy, or is not likely to be able to satisfy in future, the requirements of Rule 3.2.3, it must immediately inform the Regulator in line with Rule 3.2.5. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] Put together, the firm should use its controls to detect any actual or expected failure to keep Capital Resources at or above the Capital Requirement and then notify the Regulator immediately once that conclusion is reached. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79]

question: When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.1.2 for a Passported Fund intended to be Promoted in relevant Host Jurisdiction(s), what are the Regulator’s required steps and timing for notifying Host Regulator(s) and completing registration, and in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from transmitting the notice of intent under Rule 3.1.4(a)?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s process starts with a time-bound obligation to notify Host Regulator(s), but that transmission is barred in specified circumstances; only after Host Regulator confirmation does the Regulator complete publication and notification steps. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] Within five Business Days after receiving the notice described in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator must send a notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in each relevant Host Jurisdiction where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] However, the Regulator must not transmit that notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it considers the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply, or may in the future not comply, with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if refraining is considered necessary and appropriate to advance one or more of the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] If the notice is transmitted and the relevant Host Regulator(s) confirm their respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must then promptly (i) publish the Passported Fund’s details on the Register of Passported Funds and (ii) notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: If a Passported Fund is meant to be Promoted in a Host Jurisdiction, what does the Regulator normally do within five Business Days after getting the Rule 3.1.2 notice, what does it do after the Host Regulator(s) confirm their register is updated, and when is the Regulator not allowed to send the notice of intent under Rule 3.1.4(a)?
gold_answer: Normally, the Regulator must quickly notify the Host Regulator(s) and then, once the Host Regulator(s) confirm their register update, finish the public registration steps; but the Regulator is not allowed to send the initial notice of intent in certain cases. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] First, within five Business Days after receiving the notice mentioned in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator must send a notice to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) saying it intends to use the passporting procedures for the Passported Fund that is intended to be Promoted there. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] But the Regulator must not send that notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it thinks the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply, or might later not comply, with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it believes holding back is necessary and appropriate to support one or more of its objectives. [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] After the relevant Host Regulator(s) confirm their respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must then promptly publish the fund’s details on the Register of Passported Funds and tell the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity thinks its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive when it discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1, what does it still have to say about those assumptions, and what kind of “summary” is expected when sensitive details are not shared?
gold_answer: Even if a Mining Reporting Entity treats its material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, it still has to provide the core disclosures required for forecast financial information and cannot use sensitivity as a way to avoid meaningful disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Under Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, it must include all material economic assumptions used; if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive, it must state that view and explain the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and it must include all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, together with all information required for that Production Target (by including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, where commercially sensitive information is not disclosed, the Listing Authority expects the disclosure to still give a fair and balanced summary of the full significant terms and include any other relevant information that is Inside Information. [#TGT:5717861f-e414-48f4-8041-511cc068bfdf] A Reporting Entity also is not allowed to sidestep disclosure by calling commercially sensitive information a trade secret to try to benefit from Rule 7.2.2(1)(e). [#TGT:5717861f-e414-48f4-8041-511cc068bfdf]
