The report must state whether the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted by the Listed Entity. If the standards have not been fully adopted or have only been partially adopted, the Listed Entity must explain why full adoption did not occur and also describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. Beyond the entity’s own explanation, the annual financial report must also include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if necessary. This annual reporting structure is the practical expression of the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72] and is required content for the Listed Entity’s annual financial report [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].

question: For Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, how should an Authorised Person assess whether information derived from market-user research or analysis can still satisfy the “not generally available” limb of Inside Information, and what additional elements must be met for it to qualify as Inside Information?
gold_answer: Inside Information in this context requires a cumulative assessment. Under the definition, the information must be of a precise nature, must not be generally available, must relate directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments (or to the instruments themselves, including Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities), and must be such that, if it were generally available, it would likely have a significant effect on price [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]. The Source clarifies how to treat the “generally available” concept: information is only Inside Information if it is not generally available and has not been made available to the public, and information that can be obtained by research or analysis conducted by, or on behalf of, users of a market is to be regarded as generally available to those users [#SRC:5107d7d4-642e-466e-a4c5-17377a88b6af]. Accordingly, where the relevant market users could obtain the information through such research or analysis, it should be treated as generally available to them, meaning it would fail the “not generally available” condition even if it has not been publicly disseminated. Only if the information remains not generally available (and the other definitional criteria are met) can it qualify as Inside Information.

question: When an Issuer seeks to have a proposed Digital Security treated as a Security, what information must the Issuer provide to the FSRA to support that treatment, and how may the Regulator formalise the treatment (including any terms and conditions) by written notice?
gold_answer: Where an Issuer is seeking regulatory treatment of a proposed Digital Security as a Security, the FSRA expects the Issuer to provide the information required to demonstrate that the proposed Digital Security meets the requirements of a “Security” (as defined in FSMR). In practice, the FSRA indicates it will rely on the documentation already submitted in an Approved Prospectus process where submission of an Approved Prospectus is required, or it will review the Exempt Offer documentation where the circumstances relate to an Exempt Offer; in the latter case, the FSRA’s review is to enable its determination and is not an approval of the Exempt Offer itself [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986]. Against that evidentiary backdrop, the Regulator is permitted to act by written notice to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and Rules, and it may attach such terms and conditions as it considers appropriate to that notice [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].

question: If an Issuer wants the FSRA to treat a proposed Digital Security as a Security, what does the Issuer need to give the FSRA, and what can the Regulator do by written notice (including adding conditions) to make that treatment apply?
gold_answer: An Issuer that wants a proposed Digital Security to be treated as a Security should be prepared to provide the FSRA with the information required to show that the proposed Digital Security meets the requirements of a “Security” (as defined in FSMR). The FSRA explains that, where an Approved Prospectus must be submitted, it will use the documentation provided through that approval process to decide whether to treat the Digital Security as a Security; and where the situation involves an Exempt Offer, it will review the Exempt Offer documentation so it can make its determination, while making clear that this review is not an approval of the Exempt Offer itself [#SRC:a8ffa89d-5c3e-41da-8f68-4b1795a0d986]. Based on that kind of supporting material, the Regulator is permitted to issue a written notice that deems an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules, and it can make that notice subject to any terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c].

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and therefore must publish a Prospectus, in what circumstances is a person permitted to avoid committing a contravention relating to misleading or deceptive content in that Prospectus, and what must that person demonstrate about their enquiries and belief?
gold_answer: Where an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the regulatory requirements for Offers of Securities include an obligation to publish a Prospectus [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. In that context, the TARGET passage provides a permission-like defence for a person in relation to a contravention concerning misleading and deceptive statements or omissions in a Prospectus: the person is not treated as committing the contravention if they can prove two linked elements. First, they must have made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances. Second, after making those enquiries, they must have believed on reasonable grounds that the Prospectus was not misleading or deceptive [#TGT:39f7e2de-b1d8-46de-8603-e33e4cf70eaf]. Practically, this means that once the Prospectus publication obligation is triggered by the Issuer’s public offer, any person relying on the defence must be able to evidence both the reasonableness of the enquiries undertaken and the reasonableness of the resulting belief about the Prospectus’ accuracy and completeness, specifically as to the absence of misleading or deceptive content or omissions.

question: When an Authorised Person conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how must it ensure that the Virtual Assets it uses satisfy the maturity and market capitalisation requirements, and where are those requirements set out?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must restrict its use to Accepted Virtual Assets, meaning it should not use any Virtual Asset unless it meets the acceptance criteria applicable to that activity [#TGT:7bed5f55-c0d5-4a97-93d4-3db078c11610]. In applying that obligation, the maturity and market capitalisation requirements that inform whether a Virtual Asset can be treated as meeting the relevant acceptance standard are not contained in the operative rule text itself; instead, they are set out in the accompanying Guidance published by the Regulator concerning Virtual Assets that accompanies the chapter [#SRC:be581022-abaa-45d4-b047-d79001197dbe]. Accordingly, compliance requires the Authorised Person to consult and apply that Regulator Guidance to identify the maturity and market capitalisation thresholds or conditions, and then ensure that only Virtual Assets meeting those Guidance-based requirements are used in the Regulated Activity. This links the mandatory “only use” restriction to the defined location where the maturity/market capitalisation requirements are specified, so the Authorised Person can evidence that the Virtual Assets it uses qualify as Accepted Virtual Assets.

question: If an Authorised Person is doing a Regulated Activity involving Virtual Assets, what does it have to do about using only Accepted Virtual Assets, and where do you find the maturity and market capitalisation requirements that help determine this?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets is required to use only Accepted Virtual Assets, so it must avoid using any Virtual Asset that does not meet the applicable acceptance standard for that activity [#TGT:7bed5f55-c0d5-4a97-93d4-3db078c11610]. To apply that requirement in practice, the maturity and market capitalisation requirements that are relevant to assessing whether a Virtual Asset can satisfy the acceptance standard are not stated directly in the rule text; they are set out in the accompanying Guidance published by the Regulator concerning Virtual Assets that accompanies the chapter [#SRC:be581022-abaa-45d4-b047-d79001197dbe]. This means the Authorised Person should look to that Regulator Guidance to identify what maturity and market capitalisation conditions must be met, and then align its selection and use of Virtual Assets with those conditions so that the Virtual Assets it uses can properly be treated as Accepted Virtual Assets. In short, the obligation is in the rule, and the maturity/market capitalisation details are in the Regulator’s accompanying Guidance.

question: If a Relevant Person has to keep CDD, transaction, and suspicious activity records for at least six years, can it store them electronically, and what does it need to do so it can answer the Regulator quickly?
gold_answer: Yes. A Relevant Person must, where relevant, maintain a broad set of records, including documents and information gathered for initial and ongoing CDD or due diligence on business partners; records for the customer business relationship such as business correspondence and other account information; transaction records detailed enough to allow individual transactions to be reconstructed; and internal findings and analysis where a transaction or business appears unusual or suspicious (even if no Suspicious Activity/Transaction Report results). It must also keep internal notifications to its MLRO, Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting documents and information, communications with the FIU, specified documents, and any other matters it is expressly required to record, for at least six years based on the latest applicable trigger (report/notification date, relationship end, or Transaction completion) [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. Those required records may be kept in electronic format, but only if they are readily accessible and available so the Relevant Person can respond promptly to any requests from the Regulator for information [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618].

question: When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund becomes aware of a material event and notifies the Regulator within the required timeframe, what subsequent notification must the Regulator make to the relevant Host Regulator, and what timing standard applies to that onward notification?
gold_answer: Where the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund has a duty to notify the Regulator of material events as soon as practicable and, for specified events, no later than seven days after it becomes aware, that notification is the trigger for a further regulatory communication obligation. Specifically, once the Regulator receives the notification of the relevant changes arising from those material events, the Regulator must then notify the relevant Host Regulator of those changes, and it must do so without undue delay [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]. In practice, this creates a two-step chain: (1) the Fund Manager’s prompt reporting to the Regulator (including the outer seven-day limit for the listed categories of events), followed by (2) the Regulator’s onward notification to the relevant Host Regulator once it has received that report. The timing standards differ across the steps: the Fund Manager is constrained by “as soon as practicable” (and sometimes a hard backstop), while the Regulator’s obligation is framed as an immediate onward action without undue delay after receipt.

question: If the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund tells the Regulator about a material event, what does the Regulator then have to do with the relevant Host Regulator, and how quickly must it act?
gold_answer: The rules set up a handoff between the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund and the Regulator. First, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, and for certain listed events it must do so as soon as practicable and no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. Once the Regulator receives that kind of notification about the relevant changes, the Regulator then has its own obligation: it must notify the relevant Host Regulator of those changes, and it must do so without undue delay after receiving the notification [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]. So the Fund Manager’s prompt report to the Regulator is what starts the process, and the Regulator must then pass the information on to the relevant Host Regulator quickly, using the “without undue delay” standard. This ensures that material changes reported to the Regulator are also communicated onward to the Host Regulator in a timely way.

question: If a Payment Service Provider wants to change the Framework Contract, including any of the required contract information (like charges, exchange rates, or how notices will be sent), what does it have to give the Payment Service User, and how far in advance must it do so?
gold_answer: The Framework Contract must contain a range of required information, including (among other items) details of charges payable by the Payment Service User, where relevant the exchange rates to be applied (or how Reference Exchange Rates are determined), and the agreed means and frequency for communications and notifications, subject to an exception where a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User which is not a Natural Person otherwise agree in writing [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. If the Payment Service Provider proposes changes that would alter the existing terms of the Framework Contract or would change any information that is required to be included in the Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must provide those proposed changes to the Payment Service User [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. The deadline is fixed: the proposed changes must be provided no later than two months before the date they are intended to take effect [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. In practice, this links the contract-content obligation to the change-notification obligation: whenever required contract disclosures (such as charge details, exchange-rate information, or communication arrangements) are being updated, the Payment Service Provider must ensure the Payment Service User receives the proposed updates at least two months before the effective date, unless the written agreement exception applies [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b].

question: If a reconciliation is done under Rule 15.9.1, what written confirmation must be provided, and who inside the Authorised Person must review the reconciliation?
gold_answer: If a reconciliation is performed in accordance with Rule 15.9.1, there are two connected requirements that must both be met. The individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 must provide a written statement confirming that the reconciliation has been undertaken in accordance with the requirements of the relevant section, so there is clear written evidence that the reconciliation was carried out as required [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30]. In addition, the reconciliation performed in accordance with Rule 15.9.1 must be reviewed by a member of the Authorised Person who has adequate seniority, meaning the review must be done by someone sufficiently senior within the Authorised Person rather than by a junior staff member [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851]. Together, these obligations ensure both documentation (through the written statement) and oversight (through senior review) for reconciliations carried out under the specified reconciliation rule.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count a guarantee as credit risk mitigation and the guarantor is an MDB, what must the Authorised Person check about the MDB, and what risk weight must it apply to any CR Exposure to that MDB?
gold_answer: To use a guarantee as credit risk mitigation, an Authorised Person is permitted to recognise the guarantee’s CRM effects only if the guarantee is provided by an eligible type of entity, and one eligible category is an MDB of the relevant kind [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d]. Where the guarantor is an MDB, the Authorised Person must check that the MDB is one of the qualifying MDBs listed for the MDB asset class (including the World Bank Group entities IBRD, MIGA and IFC, and other named MDBs such as ADB, AfDB, EBRD, IADB, EIB, EIF, NIB, CDB, IDB and CEDB) [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. If the MDB is on that qualifying list, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. So the practical sequence is: confirm the guarantor fits the eligible-MDB category so the guarantee’s CRM effects can be recognised, and then apply the required 0% risk weight to the Authorised Person’s CR Exposure to that qualifying MDB [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4].

question: Where an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, must it treat the Chapter 5 requirements as exhaustive, or must it also ensure compliance with any other applicable notification requirements that may apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets (including those linked to adding further Accepted Virtual Assets)?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the specified Chapter 5 requirements, including the notification-related rules and the identified information requirements, as applicable to the circumstances described for that facility [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d]. However, those Chapter 5 requirements are not presented as the full universe of notification obligations for MTFs using Virtual Assets. The guidance explains that the notification and information requirements applied to MTFs using Virtual Assets are additional requirements and that such MTFs will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. This includes notification requirements referenced in the guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. Accordingly, compliance should be structured so that the Authorised Person both (i) meets the Chapter 5 rule set that is expressly applied to Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets and (ii) separately identifies and satisfies any other notification requirements that are applicable in the particular circumstances, including where the facility proposes to use additional Accepted Virtual Assets.

question: For notifications to the Regulator about material events affecting a Passported Fund (including changes to the Fund Manager, service providers, or commencement of winding-up), what are the mandatory form and information elements that must be provided with the notice, and by when must the notice be submitted once the relevant party becomes aware?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, and for the listed events (including retirement, removal or replacement of the Fund Manager; appointment or resignation of a material service provider, Agent or Licensed Person; commencement of winding-up; or an intention to vary or revoke a Financial Service Permission), the notice must be given as soon as practicable and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. Alongside meeting this timing requirement, the notification must comply with the Regulator’s prescribed form as directed from time to time and must, at a minimum, be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event so the Regulator can understand what has occurred and its significance [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. Where the event is that the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must also include a copy of the new Prospectus, ensuring the updated document is provided together with the event details [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

question: If the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund has to tell the Regulator about a material event, what details must be included with the notice, and how quickly must the notice be sent after the Fund Manager becomes aware?
gold_answer: When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator of a material event, the notice must be sent as soon as practicable and, for the specific events listed (such as changes to the Fund Manager, key service providers, or the Prospectus, or the start of winding-up), no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. The notice is not just a timing obligation; it also has minimum content requirements. It must be submitted in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time, and it must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event so the Regulator receives enough information to understand what happened [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. If the event is that the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced, the notice must also include a copy of the new Prospectus, so the Regulator receives the updated document together with the event description [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].

question: For an Authorised Person, in which circumstances does the chapter’s scope trigger the requirement to keep the specified Resolution Pack continuously and in a retrievable form, and what activities determine whether the Authorised Person is in-scope?
gold_answer: The requirement to maintain the specified documents and records as a “Resolution Pack” on an ongoing basis, and to be able to retrieve them in the manner described in the chapter, applies to an Authorised Person only when it is within the chapter’s stated scope [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. The chapter applies where the Authorised Person (a) holds, safeguards or administers Financial Instruments or Virtual Assets for a Client; (b) acts as Trustee, Eligible Custodian or Fund Manager of Fund; or (c) otherwise holds Client Money, Relevant Money or Safe Custody Assets in accordance with the referenced chapters [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c]. Accordingly, the applicability boundary is activity-based: if the Authorised Person performs any of these custody, administration, trustee/custodian/fund management, or money/safe-custody holding functions, it must maintain the Resolution Pack at all times and ensure it is retrievable as required by the chapter [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. If none of these conditions apply, the chapter’s requirements—including the continuous maintenance and retrievability obligation—are not triggered [#TGT:d5c306cd-f521-4933-8a2e-3788cde7e07c].

question: When an Authorised Person takes reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them, what must the Authorised Person ensure about the form and content of any conflict-of-interest disclosure made to a Client so the Client can make an informed decision in relation to the relevant service?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them, and these requirements apply in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Where a conflict of interest arises in the context of providing a service to a Client and a disclosure is made, the disclosure must meet specific delivery and content standards: it must be made in a durable medium and it must include sufficient detail, taking into account the nature of the Client, to enable that Client to take an informed decision with respect to the service in the context of which the conflict of interest arises [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]. Read together, the Authorised Person’s conflict identification and prevention/management steps should be supported by a disclosure process that is capable of producing a durable record and tailoring the level of detail to the Client’s characteristics, so that the disclosure meaningfully informs the Client’s decision about the relevant service rather than being generic or purely formal.

question: If an Authorised Person finds an actual or potential conflict of interest, what must it do to make sure any disclosure to the Client is delivered properly and gives enough detail for the Client to decide about the service?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them, and this applies in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. If, in the context of a service, a conflict of interest arises and the Authorised Person makes a disclosure to the Client, the disclosure has to satisfy two core requirements. First, it must be made in a durable medium, meaning it is provided in a form that can be retained and referred to later [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]. Second, it must include enough detail—adjusted for the nature of the Client—so the Client can make an informed decision about the service in which the conflict arises [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]. In practice, the identification and prevention/management steps should feed into a disclosure that is specific to the conflict and the service, and is detailed enough for that particular Client to understand the issue and decide how to proceed.

question: For purposes of scope, which Authorised Person categories are covered, and how does the general applicability statement compare with the limitation that only certain parts apply?
gold_answer: Across the paired provisions, the scope is framed around the same actor and the same category limitation, but it is expressed at different levels of granularity. In the SOURCE, the applicability statement is broad: it indicates that the relevant Section applies to an Authorised Person, but only where that Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5 [#SRC:f8e6e2e9-e736-491d-80c4-9a959458b527]. In the TARGET, the scope is narrower in structure: it specifies that only particular parts within the broader framework—Sections 8.2 to 8.4—apply, and they apply only to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 [#TGT:6bf50729-bccd-4188-840f-d3ed2ff4e9a5]. Read together, both texts align on who is in-scope (an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5), while the TARGET clarifies that the “only” limitation is tied to a subset of the overall material, whereas the SOURCE describes applicability at the Section level without that internal subdivision.

question: Who do these rules apply to, and do they apply to the whole section or only to certain parts?
gold_answer: Both passages set the scope by identifying the same actor and the same category filter: they apply to an Authorised Person, but only if that Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5. The difference is how much of the material is being scoped. The SOURCE states that the Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5, which presents the applicability at the level of the Section as a whole [#SRC:f8e6e2e9-e736-491d-80c4-9a959458b527]. The TARGET, however, makes clear that only certain parts—Sections 8.2 to 8.4—apply, and it repeats the same “only” limitation to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 [#TGT:6bf50729-bccd-4188-840f-d3ed2ff4e9a5]. Taken together, you should treat Category 1, 2 and 5 as the in-scope categories for an Authorised Person, and also recognize that the TARGET explicitly confines applicability to a defined subset of the overall content rather than implying that every part applies.

question: If the Regulator thinks a person is not fit and proper for a Controlled Function and may withdraw their Approval, what kinds of things will the Regulator look at before deciding to use that power?
gold_answer: If the Regulator considers that a person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question, it may withdraw the person’s Approval for that Controlled Function [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]. Before deciding whether to use that power, the Regulator will have regard to all relevant matters, not just a single factor [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c]. Those matters include the criteria used to assess the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person, and whether the Approved Person has committed any offences or has been the subject of a finding involving dishonesty, fraud, or a financial crime. The Regulator will also consider whether other enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, against the Approved Person by the Regulator itself or by other enforcement agencies. In addition, the Regulator looks at the specific Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing, the nature and activities of the firm concerned, and the markets in which the firm operates. It also weighs how severe the risk is to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system.

question: What control and approval features must the Authorised Person build into the Liquidity Risk control system included in its strategy to ensure both effective implementation of the required framework and demonstrable adherence to Liquidity Risk management processes?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must embed a system for controlling Liquidity Risk within its strategy that is not merely descriptive but operationally capable of implementing the required framework [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647]. To make that implementation effective and controllable, the Authorised Person must ensure the system includes appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms designed to provide reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are adhered to [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]. The system must also be structured so that the Authorised Person's Governing Body and senior management can review compliance with the relevant limits and operating procedures, supporting ongoing oversight and challenge as part of the control environment [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]. Taken together, these elements mean the strategy must incorporate a control system that both enables implementation of the applicable requirements and contains governance-facing review capabilities and internal approval/limit mechanisms that help ensure Liquidity Risk processes are followed consistently in practice [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647].

question: In the Liquidity Risk strategy, what must the Authorised Person include in the control system so it can carry out the required Liquidity Risk requirements and also let the Authorised Person's Governing Body and senior management check compliance and enforce adherence?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must ensure its strategy includes a system for controlling Liquidity Risk that can be used to implement the required Liquidity Risk requirements that the strategy is meant to support [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647]. Beyond being capable of implementation, the Authorised Person must ensure the system is built with oversight and control features. It must enable the Authorised Person's Governing Body and senior management to review compliance with the relevant limits and operating procedures, so that senior oversight is possible and ongoing [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]. The system must also have appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms designed to provide reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are adhered to, meaning there are internal steps and controls that help ensure people follow the Liquidity Risk processes consistently [#SRC:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]. In combination, these requirements ensure the strategy’s control system both supports implementation and provides governance review and practical mechanisms to drive adherence [#TGT:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647].

question: Where an Authorised Person has structured a Synthetic Securitisation so that it meets the conditions for exclusion from the calculation of RWA, does the Authorised Person nevertheless have to maintain regulatory capital for any securitisation Exposures it retains, and how should that obligation be reconciled with the exclusion criteria?
gold_answer: Even if a Synthetic Securitisation satisfies the requirements to be excluded from the calculation of RWA, that exclusion does not remove the separate obligation on the Authorised Person to hold regulatory capital against any securitisation Exposures it retains. The Source establishes a clear, continuing capital requirement: an Authorised Person that meets the relevant conditions must still hold regulatory capital for retained securitisation Exposures, meaning the capital treatment for what is retained persists regardless of whether the Synthetic Securitisation otherwise qualifies for an RWA calculation exclusion [#SRC:81454e3f-1d3a-45a7-bb48-463be428494c]. The Target, by contrast, frames the distinct concept of “Requirements in order for a Synthetic Securitisation to be excluded from the calculation of RWA,” which addresses when the Synthetic Securitisation may be left out of the RWA computation [#TGT:3c639964-d4ab-40e1-a349-4cd4d1acf7a9]. Read together, the practical reconciliation is that the exclusion criteria govern whether the Synthetic Securitisation is excluded from RWA, while the Source obligation governs the Authorised Person’s ongoing regulatory capital for any securitisation Exposures it retains.

question: If a Synthetic Securitisation meets the requirements to be left out of the RWA calculation, does an Authorised Person still need to hold regulatory capital for any securitisation Exposures it keeps?
gold_answer: Yes. The fact that a Synthetic Securitisation may meet the requirements to be excluded from the calculation of RWA does not, by itself, eliminate the need for the Authorised Person to hold regulatory capital against securitisation Exposures it retains. The Source states that an Authorised Person meeting the relevant conditions must still hold regulatory capital against any securitisation Exposures it retains, which makes the capital obligation explicit and continuing for retained exposures [#SRC:81454e3f-1d3a-45a7-bb48-463be428494c]. The Target focuses on a different but related issue: it identifies the “Requirements in order for a Synthetic Securitisation to be excluded from the calculation of RWA,” i.e., the criteria that determine whether the Synthetic Securitisation can be left out of the RWA computation [#TGT:3c639964-d4ab-40e1-a349-4cd4d1acf7a9]. Taken together, you should treat the RWA exclusion requirements as governing the RWA calculation treatment of the Synthetic Securitisation, while separately ensuring regulatory capital is still held for any securitisation Exposures the Authorised Person retains.

question: For an Authorised Person, how do the prohibitions on incurring Large Exposures in the Non Trading Book and on holding counterparty exposures when Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA jointly constrain concentration risk, including the relevant percentage caps and the financing basis for those caps?
gold_answer: Both passages impose concentration prohibitions on an Authorised Person, but they apply in different contexts and must be read together to manage overall exposure risk. Under the Large Exposures limits, an Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and also faces a Trading Book constraint) where, after taking into account eligible CRM, the exposure would exceed 25% of its Tier 1 [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Separately, when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it is prohibited from having an Exposure to a Counterparty (including Connected Counterparty groupings and groups of Closely Related Counterparties) above specified percentages of its Capital Resources, with the applicable cap depending on whether the exposure is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs (25%), or by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs (40%) [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]. In practice, the firm must ensure both the Non Trading Book Large Exposures ceiling and the PSIA counterparty exposure ceilings are not breached, applying the relevant measure (Tier 1 vs Capital Resources) and financing basis.

question: An Authorised Person must not take on certain big exposures. How do the rules on Large Exposures in the Non Trading Book and the limits that apply when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA work together, and what percentage limits apply?
gold_answer: The two passages set separate “must not” limits that an Authorised Person needs to satisfy at the same time, depending on where the exposure sits and whether it relates to Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA. First, for Large Exposures limits, the Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and also has a Trading Book restriction) if, after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM, the exposure would exceed 25% of its Tier 1 [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f]. Second, when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must not have an Exposure to a Counterparty (including a Connected Counterparty, a group of Closely Related Counterparties, or a group of Connected Counterparties) that exceeds set percentages of its Capital Resources [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]. The cap is 25% if the exposure is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, and 40% if financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. So, the firm must check both the Tier 1-based Large Exposures cap and the Capital Resources-based PSIA counterparty caps.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and relies on the permission not to comply with the otherwise applicable requirement, what must it include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources if those Non-Equivalent Estimates were previously disclosed but have not been subsequently disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, including where more than three years have passed since first disclosure?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it is permitted not to comply with the otherwise applicable requirement, but only provided it complies with the specified related requirements, including Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4 and Rule 11.7.6 [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. Where the Mining Reporting Entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates in compliance with Rule 11.7.3 and those estimates have not subsequently been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, it must disclose in its Summary of Reserves and Resources: the steps taken to evaluate the previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates; the status of any further evaluation and/or exploration work required to verify and disclose them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with the Mining Reporting Standard; and the status of the proposed source of funding for that evaluation and/or exploration work [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907]. If more than three years have passed since first disclosure under Rule 11.7.4 and the estimates still have not been verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, it must also disclose why, and its intention, proposed timetable, and proposed source of funding for verification and disclosure [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907].

question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change any of the required information in the Governing Contract (like service details, fees, or how the parties communicate), what does the Third Party Provider have to send to the Customer, and how far in advance of the effective date?
gold_answer: The Governing Contract between a Third Party Provider and their Customers is required to contain a defined set of information unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing. This includes, among other items, information about the Third Party Provider (identity and ADGM contact details and regulatory/FSP details), the Third Party Services (including consent process and timing), charges and exchange rates, communication methods and frequency, safeguards and corrective measures, change/termination terms, and redress provisions [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. When the Third Party Provider proposes to change either (i) the existing terms of the Governing Contract or (ii) the information that is required to be included in the contract, the Third Party Provider must provide those proposed changes to the Customer no later than two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]. So, if any of the contract’s required disclosures are being updated, the Customer must receive the proposed updated terms/information at least two months in advance of the planned effective date.

question: If the Regulator can direct a Recognised Body about its Controllers to help meet the Regulator’s operational objectives, what does the Regulator need to look at before deciding to use that power?
gold_answer: The Regulator is permitted to give a direction to a Recognised Body on matters relating to its Controllers when it considers giving the direction is desirable to advance one or more of its operational objectives [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81]. Before it decides it is appropriate to use that power, the Regulator must consider all relevant information and factors [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]. The factors it must take into account include: the Rules contained in MIR; what it has learned from its routine supervision of the Recognised Body; and how much any failure (or likely failure) to meet one or more Recognition Requirements could affect the Regulator’s objectives [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]. Put simply, even though the Regulator can direct the Recognised Body for objective-related reasons, it should first check the relevant MIR Rules, review supervisory results, and assess the potential impact of actual or expected shortfalls against Recognition Requirements on the Regulator’s objectives, so the decision to direct is grounded in the full set of relevant considerations [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81].

question: If a Person seeks one of the specified ADGM Green/Climate Transition designations and is later granted that designation, how do the required payments differ between the initial application and the first and subsequent calendar years of holding the designation?
gold_answer: The required payments operate in two stages tied to different events. First, at the point of applying to the Regulator for any of the specified designations (including ADGM Green Fund, ADGM Climate Transition Fund, ADGM Green Portfolio, ADGM Climate Transition Portfolio, ADGM Green Bond, or ADGM Sustainability Linked Bond), the Person must pay an application fee of $2,000 to the Regulator [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b]. Second, if the Person is granted a designation, the Person must pay an annual designation fee of $2,000 to the Regulator [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc]. The first annual designation fee is not necessarily a full-year amount: it must be prorated for the remainder of the calendar year following the initial granting of the designation, aligning the fee to the portion of the year during which the designation is held [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc]. For subsequent calendar years commencing 1 January, the annual designation fee becomes payable in full, and it must be paid on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc].

question: When an Authorised Person determines risk-weighted amounts for securitisation Exposures, how must it apply the prescribed Exposure measurement methodology to establish each Exposure value, and how does that value then flow through the subsequent grading and risk-weighting steps to produce the final aggregated RWA outcome?
gold_answer: The Exposure measurement methodology sets the required approach for calculating Exposures specifically for determining Credit RWA for securitisation (SE) Exposures [#SRC:84ee9ffb-686e-47d9-b971-908e8cec77f1]. Consistent with that prescription, an Authorised Person calculating RWA for all its SE Exposures must first determine the Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and must recognise the effects of any applicable CRM in that measurement step [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]. After establishing the Exposure value, the Authorised Person must allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for the SE Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11, and then calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure (other than those required to be included as deductions from any component of Capital Resources) using the stated formula in which the Exposure value is multiplied by the applicable risk weight derived from the grade. Finally, it must add together the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures and combine them with RWA amounts calculated for Early Amortisation Exposures as required.

question: When the conditions for applying the central government and central bank asset class risk-weighting approach are not satisfied, how must an Authorised Person treat the CR Exposure, and how does that interact with the obligation to apply the table-based risk weights for that asset class?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to risk weight any CR Exposure that falls within the central government and central bank asset class by applying the risk weights set out in the specified table, which assigns a percentage risk weight by Credit Quality Grade (including an unrated category) [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]. However, this table-based obligation is expressly subject to the conditions referenced for that asset class, and the procedural direction is that where those conditions are not met, the CR Exposure must instead be treated under the alternative treatment specified for that scenario [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938]. In practice, the compliance sequence is: first determine whether the relevant conditions are met for using the central government and central bank asset class framework; if they are met, apply the table to assign the appropriate risk weight by the applicable Credit Quality Grade or unrated status; if they are not met, do not proceed with the table-based risk weighting for that exposure and apply the alternative treatment required for non-fulfilment of those conditions [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938].

question: When an Authorised Person measures pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from an SFT and has taken eligible financial Collateral but the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, how must the Authorised Person determine the adjusted exposure amount to be used in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation, given the framework for calculating E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions?
gold_answer: For pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs, where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA, the Authorised Person must calculate an adjusted exposure amount (E*) in accordance with the applicable Rules referenced for that purpose, and then use that E* figure in place of the unadjusted exposure (E) when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure. This obligation applies specifically to the measurement of E for such pre-settlement exposures and is tied to the requirement to substitute E* for E in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation. The relevant E* methodology is the one intended for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions, aligning the calculation approach to the collateralised nature of the SFT while excluding those other transaction categories. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] [#TGT:ba7703d2-eb05-4b88-b13a-0dfe34dd09bd]

question: If a Payment Order for one Payment Transaction is sent using a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract, what details must the Payment Service Provider give right after the Payment Order is started, and what general details can it skip because another Payment Service Provider covers them under the Framework Contract?
gold_answer: Even when the Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider handling that single transaction must still provide or make available specific information immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order to the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee. That required information includes: confirmation that the Payment Order was successfully initiated with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider; a reference that lets the Payer and Payee identify the Payment Transaction (including the Payer and Payee and any information transferred with the Payment Order); the amount and currency used; any charges payable (and, where applicable, a breakdown); any exchange rate used (or a reference) and the amount after conversion; the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order; and the Credit Value Date [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622]. However, for that same scenario, the Payment Service Provider for the single Payment Transaction does not have to provide or make available the general information where that general information has been provided or will be provided under the Framework Contract by another Payment Service Provider, which is the permission described [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2].

question: When the Mining Reporting Entity puts one of these mining statements in a Prospectus, what sustainability information must the Prospectus include, and what rules must the disclosure be prepared under?
gold_answer: When the Mining Reporting Entity includes in a Prospectus a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, it must do two things at the same time. First, it must make sure the disclosure is prepared in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and this chapter, so the statement is produced under the required disclosure framework [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. Second, the Prospectus must include details in relation to the Mining Reporting Entity’s policies and practices for operating in a sustainable manner. This includes the Mining Reporting Entity’s policy with regards to environmental and social issues, the impact of the Mining Reporting Entity’s business practices on the environment and the communities in which it operates, and the environmental and social risks faced by the Mining Reporting Entity [#SRC:ac70dcf0-7928-4d1c-9561-1b88ff273cb9]. So, compliance requires both a properly prepared mining disclosure and a Prospectus section that clearly explains the entity’s sustainability policies, impacts, and risks.

question: When the Regulator receives the notice that triggers its duty to notify Host Regulator(s) of an intent to use passporting procedures, in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from transmitting the related notice, and how does that prohibition affect the timing of the Regulator’s subsequent notifications and publication steps?
gold_answer: Upon receipt of the notice that initiates the passporting process, the Regulator is generally required to act within a defined timeframe by providing notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the relevant Host Regulator(s) in the Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted, and then to complete follow-on steps after Host Regulator confirmation (publication on the Register of Passported Funds and notification to the Fund Manager that registration is complete) [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. However, the Regulator is prohibited from transmitting the related notice in specified circumstances: where it considers the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including the Rules), or where it has reasonable grounds to determine they may not comply in the future; and where it considers refraining is necessary and appropriate to further one or more of its objectives [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. In those prohibited scenarios, the Regulator cannot proceed with the transmission step that would ordinarily support the downstream obligations, meaning the five Business Day notification to Host Regulator(s) and the subsequent publication/notification sequence would not be actioned on the basis of that transmission until the prohibition no longer applies, and any action remains subject to the stated conditions in the obligation.

question: If the Regulator is supposed to tell Host Regulator(s) about using the passporting procedures within a set number of Business Days, when is the Regulator not allowed to send the related notice, and what does that mean for publishing the Passported Fund details and telling the Fund Manager registration is complete?
gold_answer: The Regulator has a structured set of required steps once it receives the relevant notice: it must, within five Business Days, provide notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in the Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted, and then, after the Host Regulator(s) confirm their Register has been updated, it must publish the Passported Fund details on the Register of Passported Funds and notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete [#TGT:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. But the Regulator is not allowed to transmit the related notice in two situations: (1) if it considers the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including the Rules), or it has reasonable grounds to think they may not comply in the future; or (2) if it considers it is necessary and appropriate to refrain in order to further one or more of its objectives [#SRC:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. If either situation applies, the Regulator must refrain from that transmission, and the later steps that depend on progressing the passporting process—timely notice to Host Regulator(s), then publication and completion notification—would not proceed on the basis of a notice the Regulator is prohibited from sending.

question: When assessing the scope of whether a Recognised Clearing House should be treated as non-compliant due to an inability to settle a particular transaction, how may the FSRA take into account a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility’s clearing and settlement framework and related safeguards for timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House is not, by scope, to be treated as failing to comply with the applicable Recognition Requirement solely because it cannot arrange settlement of a particular transaction [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]. In parallel, where the FSRA is determining whether there are satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of parties to transactions, it is permitted to have regard to a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility’s (SCSF’s) arrangements and controls across the clearing and settlement lifecycle [#SRC:b5d36396-57ff-473e-8ff9-0e392516e731]. This includes the SCSF’s rules and practices for clearing and settlement (including any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), trade matching and confirmation processes, delivery and payment arrangements in relevant jurisdictions, and procedures to detect and address a Member’s (or participant’s) failure to settle. It also covers mechanisms to take action to settle when a Member does not, monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, and the SCSF’s Default Rules and default procedures, all of which inform the FSRA’s view of whether settlement arrangements are satisfactory notwithstanding an isolated settlement inability.

question: When a Relevant Person is permitted to rely on a third party for elements of CDD, what jurisdiction-equivalence assessment must it perform and what concrete reliance conditions must be met before and during that reliance?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person may rely on a third party for relevant elements of CDD only within a tightly conditioned framework. First, it must assess whether the third party is regulated (including for AML/TFS compliance) by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country whose AML/TFS regulations are equivalent to FATF standards, and that the third party is supervised for compliance; this equivalence assessment must take into account a range of factors such as international mutual evaluations and assessment reports, relevant memberships, contextual indicators like political stability and corruption, evidence of recent criticism (including advisory notices and public assessments), and whether there are adequate co-operation arrangements between the foreign AML/TFS regulator and the Regulator [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] and [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]. In addition, the Relevant Person must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information, take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of underlying documents will be available on request without delay, ensure the third party has not relied on an exception for the CDD elements being relied upon, and ensure the information is up to date where required [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275].

question: When the Regulator requests information previously submitted to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, what must a Representative Office provide, and how may the Regulator use that information in its supervisory assessment?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator makes a request, a Representative Office is required to provide the Regulator with the information that the Representative Office itself, or another member of its Group, has already provided to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003]. This obligation operates in the context of group supervision, because the information obtained through such requests may be taken into account by the Regulator as part of its fit and proper test and in the supervision of the firm [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050]. In practice, this means the Representative Office should be prepared to identify and supply the relevant materials that have been shared externally by it or its Group, so the Regulator can consider them alongside other supervisory inputs. The linkage between the request-and-provide requirement and the Regulator’s ability to take the information into account underscores that the purpose of providing the information is not merely administrative; it supports the Regulator’s assessment of fitness and propriety and ongoing supervisory oversight of the firm.

question: If the Regulator asks, what information does a Representative Office have to give about what it (or its Group) has already sent to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator, and what can the Regulator do with that information?
gold_answer: If the Regulator requests it, a Representative Office must give the Regulator the information that the Representative Office or another member of its Group has already provided to a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator [#TGT:8519a0fd-97e3-4184-8a8f-7807db5de003]. This sits within group supervision, because the Regulator can take that information into account when applying its fit and proper test and when supervising the firm more generally [#SRC:9f4ba591-cf28-4b21-8577-813e8f071050]. So, the Representative Office’s duty is triggered by a request, and the scope covers information previously shared outside ADGM by the Representative Office itself or its wider Group. The practical effect is that the same information that has been provided to another financial services regulator may need to be provided again to the Regulator, and the Regulator may then use it as an input to assess fitness and propriety and to inform ongoing supervisory work.

question: Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, how may the Customer and the Third Party Provider vary by written agreement the application of the Third Party Provider’s duty to be liable for charges and interest arising from the non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of a Third Party Transaction?
gold_answer: The Third Party Provider must be liable to its Customer for charges the Customer is responsible for and for any interest the Customer must pay when a Third Party Transaction is not executed, is defectively executed, or is executed late due to the Third Party Provider’s actions or failures [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151]. However, where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider are permitted to agree in writing that certain specified rules do not apply, including the rule addressing liability for charges, which is the mechanism that can alter how that liability framework applies between them [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. In practice, this means the baseline obligation in the liability provision applies unless the parties have made a valid written agreement (and the Customer meets the “not a Natural Person” condition) to disapply the relevant rule(s). Any such agreement operates as a contractual variation of the default regulatory allocation of responsibility for charges and related interest in the circumstances described.

question: Where an Authorised Person both operates as a Cell Company and holds a Financial Services Permission to carry on Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how must the Cell-based component be calculated?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person in this combined position must account for two separate annual supervision fee obligations payable to the Regulator, each triggered by different characteristics of the Authorised Person’s business. First, because the Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee comprised of a fixed amount for the Cell Company plus a variable amount that scales with the number of Cells (i.e., a base $8,000 for the Cell Company and $1,000 for each Cell). This Cell Company amount is expressly described as an “additional” annual supervision fee and therefore must be calculated by identifying the Cell Company status and counting the Cells to determine the per-Cell component [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. Second, because the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance and/or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must also pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000 for either or both Regulated Activities [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].

question: If an Authorised Person is a Cell Company and also does insurance business as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, what yearly fees must it pay to the Regulator, and how do Cells affect the amount?
gold_answer: In that situation, the Authorised Person has two fee obligations that apply for different reasons and both are payable to the Regulator. Because it operates as a Cell Company, it must pay an additional annual supervision fee made up of two parts: a fixed $8,000 for the Cell Company itself, plus $1,000 for each Cell. That means the total Cell Company-related amount increases as the number of Cells increases, so the Authorised Person must determine how many Cells it has in order to calculate the per-Cell portion correctly [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b]. Separately, if the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as a Captive Insurer or an Insurance Special Purpose Vehicle, it must pay an annual supervision fee of $5,000, and that $5,000 applies for either or both of those Regulated Activities [#TGT:9240b52a-9167-41c8-a2aa-aba636e47579].

question: If a person is trying to comply with a requirement under this Part (or a Part 17 requirement), what must they not do if the information they give is materially false or misleading, and does it matter whether they knew it was wrong or were just reckless?
gold_answer: A person must not give information that is false or misleading in a material particular when they are presenting it as part of complying with a requirement. The TARGET states that, in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under the Part, a person is prohibited from providing information they know is materially false or misleading, and is also prohibited from recklessly providing materially false or misleading information [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96]. The SOURCE mirrors this approach in the Part 17 context by treating deliberate or reckless provision of materially false or misleading information in purported compliance with a Part 17 requirement as non-compliance that amounts to a contravention [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23]. Taken together, it matters in the sense that both mental states are covered: the rule applies whether the person knowingly supplies materially wrong information or supplies it while being reckless about its truth or accuracy, so long as it is given as if to meet the requirement.

question: When an Applicant must demonstrate compliance with the audited accounts publication/filing requirement, under what conditions may the Regulator modify or waive that requirement, and how does the investor-information test interact with the minimum prior period coverage of three years (or a shorter period the Regulator accepts)?
gold_answer: An Applicant is required to have published or filed audited accounts that meet specified criteria, including that they cover a prior period of three years, unless a shorter period is acceptable to the Regulator, and that they are consolidated, prepared under acceptable standards, and audited under IAASB or other acceptable auditing standards [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. In parallel, the Regulator has discretion to modify or waive the relevant requirement if it is satisfied that doing so is desirable in the interests of investors and that investors have the necessary information available to arrive at an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares for which admission to the Official List is sought [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca]. Read together, the Applicant’s baseline obligation is to provide audited financial statements meeting the three years coverage benchmark (or an accepted shorter period), but the Regulator’s ability to modify or waive hinges on an investor-protection assessment: the Regulator must be satisfied both that the modification/waiver serves investors’ interests and that investors still have sufficient information to make an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares.

question: For an Authorised Person working out which capital instruments to include in Available Stable Funding, what does AT1 Capital include, and how does that definition affect what the Authorised Person must identify?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must identify the capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by looking at which capital elements meet the stated eligibility requirements and then selecting the instruments for inclusion on that basis [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. If the Authorised Person is considering instruments that fall within AT1 Capital, the AT1 definition clarifies what must be counted as that capital element: AT1 Capital is made up of two components—capital instruments that meet the applicable eligibility criteria and the share premium accounts related to those instruments [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b]. This means that, when identifying what to include for ASF purposes, the Authorised Person should not stop at listing only the qualifying AT1 instruments; it should also recognise any related share premium accounts as part of the AT1 Capital element being assessed, while continuing to apply the ASF identification approach that is based on the relevant eligibility requirements and any exclusions specified for instruments being included [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1].

question: In an MTF admission deal, how do you tell whether the “up to 200 non-Professional Clients” part is an Exempt Offer, and what does the rule allow the Issuer to add alongside it?
gold_answer: To decide whether the “up to 200 non-Professional Clients” part is an Exempt Offer, you must match it to the Regulator’s prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances. The relevant circumstance applies (other than for Debentures and Sukuk) where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. So the key checks are: ADGM nexus, the 200-person cap, the offeree categories, and the platform/MTF condition. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Where the Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in the circumstance described in the SOURCE, the Issuer may also utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more other Exempt Offer circumstances from the same set, with the stated exception. Practically, the Issuer can add a second Exempt Offer tranche at the same time, such as an Offer directed only at Professional Clients, while keeping the non-Professional Client tranche within the capped conditions. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]

question: For purposes of the obligation to calculate NSFR at an appropriate frequency and also when changes to Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding could materially affect NSFR, which Authorised Person categories are within scope of that expectation, and who is outside it?
gold_answer: The expectation to calculate NSFR with an appropriate frequency—so the firm can monitor its ongoing satisfaction of the NSFR requirement at all times—and to perform additional calculations when the firm believes a change to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding may materially change its NSFR, applies only where the entity is an Authorised Person that falls within the categories covered by the relevant Section. Specifically, the scope limitation is that the Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. Accordingly, an Authorised Person in any of those categories should implement a process to calculate its NSFR at a frequency that enables continuous monitoring and to trigger additional calculations when it believes ASF or RSF has changed in a way that might materially affect NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. Conversely, an Authorised Person not in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 is outside the stated scope of this Section and therefore is not captured by this particular expectation as framed here [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

question: If an Authorised Person needs to work out its NSFR often enough to keep track of compliance and also re-calculate when it thinks Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding has changed in a way that could materially move NSFR, which categories of Authorised Person does this apply to?
gold_answer: This expectation applies only to the Authorised Persons that fall within the Section’s stated scope. The scope statement is that the Section applies to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. For an Authorised Person in one of those categories, it should calculate its NSFR with an appropriate frequency so that it can monitor, at all times, whether it is satisfying the NSFR requirement, and it should also do an additional NSFR calculation where it believes a change has happened to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding that might cause a material change in its NSFR level [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. In other words, the text sets both a regular monitoring expectation (the frequency must be “appropriate” to allow continuous monitoring) and a specific trigger for extra calculations (the firm’s belief that ASF or RSF has changed in a way that could materially affect NSFR) [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. If an Authorised Person is not in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, it is outside this Section’s scope [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

question: Who is covered by the rule that says an Authorised Person should calculate NSFR regularly and also when it thinks a change to Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding could materially change NSFR?
gold_answer: Coverage depends on the Section’s scope and the NSFR-calculation expectation described. The Section is expressly limited to an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759]. Within that scope, the expectation is that an Authorised Person should calculate its NSFR with an appropriate frequency to ensure it can monitor its satisfaction of the NSFR requirement at all times, and it should also calculate NSFR additionally where it believes that a change has happened to its Available Stable Funding or Required Stable Funding that might result in a material change to the level of its NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. So, the covered population is not “all firms,” but only Authorised Persons in those listed categories, and for them the obligation has two parts: ongoing calculations frequent enough for continuous monitoring, plus extra calculations when the firm believes ASF or RSF has changed in a way that could materially affect NSFR [#SRC:50aee557-426a-475b-bbf3-73ca3ea00933]. Authorised Persons outside Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5 are not within the Section’s stated scope [#TGT:c6a601d3-a2ca-464f-820c-bdd74b7e1759].

question: For an Authorised Person whose dealing activity is limited to acting only to execute Clients’ orders, what conditions must be satisfied for it to be treated as Dealing in Investments as a Matched Principal, and how does that classification affect which category its dealing activities fall within?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person’s dealing activities are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, those activities fall within the scope of Category 3A, rather than being treated as Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) for Category 2 purposes [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. An Authorised Person is treated as Dealing in Investments as a Matched Principal only if it enters into transactions as a principal solely to fulfil its Clients’ orders, and any positions it holds for its own account arise only because Clients’ orders could not be matched [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. In addition, the total market value of those positions must not exceed 15% of the Firm’s Tier 1 Capital Resources, and the positions must be incidental and held only for the time reasonably required to carry out a transaction of that nature [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. Read together, the source establishes the category consequence of being limited to Matched Principal activity, while the target provides the operative criteria that must be met to rely on that classification [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc].

question: If an Authorised Person says it only deals to fill Clients’ orders, what does it need to do (and not do) to count as acting as a Matched Principal, and what category does that put its dealing activities into?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person’s dealing activities are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the source text states that those dealing activities fall within Category 3A [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. To count as Dealing in Investments as a Matched Principal, the target definition requires that the Authorised Person enters into transactions as a principal only to fulfil its Clients’ orders, rather than taking principal risk for its own purposes [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. It may hold positions for its own account only when it fails to match Clients’ orders, and even then the total market value of those positions must be no more than 15% of the Firm’s Tier 1 Capital Resources [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc]. The positions must also be incidental and strictly limited to the time reasonably required to carry out a transaction of that nature [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc].
