Putting these together: meeting the target conditions supports the “Matched Principal” label, and being limited to that activity drives the Category 3A treatment described in the source [#SRC:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] [#TGT:36237c4c-0aef-4cdf-879a-4f72f0c1facc].

question: When an MTF or OTF uses arrangements to make trading information public, what conditions must those arrangements meet, and how does that obligation align with the expectation for how publicly released information should be formatted and the discretion a Recognised Investment Exchange has over the structure it uses?
gold_answer: Where an MTF or OTF uses arrangements to make information public (including trading information that must be disclosed), those arrangements must meet multiple operational conditions: they must be reliable, monitored continuously, and make the information available to the public on a non-discriminatory basis [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef]. In addition to these conditions, the dissemination format must be consistent and structured, even though the venue can choose the particular format structure it uses [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef]. This aligns with the expectation that information made public should conform to a consistent and structured format based on industry standards, while also recognising that Recognised Investment Exchanges can choose the structure they use [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504]. Taken together, the requirements and expectations point to a combined compliance outcome: the publication mechanism must be operationally robust and fair in access, and the output must be presented in a consistent, structured way, with flexibility on the chosen structure so long as it meets the consistency/structure standard and, in the target framing, reflects industry standards [#SRC:86058b68-1cad-488d-9bd7-2d6bdd750bef] [#TGT:dd3d6160-82a8-4962-8bbc-287a50285504].

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person seeks approval from the FSRA to conduct a Regulated Activity in relation to both conventional assets and Virtual Assets, may the Regulator exercise discretion to reduce or waive fees so that the fees attributable to the Authorised Person are not cumulative, and on what basis and timing can such relief be granted?
gold_answer: Yes. In the scenario where an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets and therefore must seek approval from the FSRA for both asset types, the fee outcome may be affected by discretionary relief. The SOURCE explains that, although fees are attributable to the Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities across both conventional and Virtual Asset-related activities, those fees “may not be cumulative” where the FSRA applies its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, and it also encourages early engagement with the FSRA on fee questions [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689]. The TARGET sets out the general permission for relief: the Regulator may at any time reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) if, in the circumstances of the particular case, it considers it fair and reasonable to do so [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]. Read together, the Regulator’s “fair and reasonable” assessment provides the basis for exercising discretion, and the SOURCE indicates that such discretion can prevent cumulative fee outcomes in the dual-asset approval context.

question: If an Applicant/Authorised Person needs FSRA approval to do Regulated Activities for both conventional assets and Virtual Assets, can the Regulator reduce or waive fees so the fees are not added together, and when can it do that?
gold_answer: It can, depending on the circumstances. The SOURCE explains that when an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets, it needs to seek approval from the FSRA for both asset types, and it notes that the fees attributable to that Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities across both categories may not be cumulative if the FSRA applies its discretion to reduce or waive a fee; it also recommends discussing fee questions with the FSRA as early as practicable [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689]. The TARGET provides the broader rule on relief: the Regulator may at any time reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) if it considers that, in the circumstances of a particular case, it would be fair and reasonable to do so [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]. Putting these together, the Regulator’s ability to grant fee relief “at any time” and based on what is fair and reasonable is the mechanism that can support a non-cumulative fee outcome in the dual-asset approval situation.

question: What systems and controls must an Authorised Person maintain to ensure it does not accept a referral of a Retail Client from an unregulated Person in any circumstance where the Authorised Person would disburse a monetary or non-monetary reward to that unregulated Person?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain adequate systems and controls designed to ensure compliance with the relevant rule framework [#SRC:83c756d9-3a60-4744-a066-c56fbb204047]. In practice, those systems and controls must be sufficient to prevent the specific prohibited conduct of accepting a referral of a Retail Client made by an unregulated Person where acceptance involves the Authorised Person disbursing any reward—whether monetary or non-monetary—to the unregulated Person [#TGT:eb92921c-abc1-4657-8789-809b31e91b25]. Accordingly, the control environment should be capable of identifying when a Retail Client has been referred, determining whether the referrer is an unregulated Person, and detecting whether any reward (in cash or in kind) would be paid or provided by the Authorised Person to that referrer in connection with the referral. If those conditions are present, the systems and controls must ensure the referral is not accepted, because the prohibition applies to the acceptance of the referral in that reward-linked scenario [#TGT:eb92921c-abc1-4657-8789-809b31e91b25], and the obligation is to have controls adequate to ensure compliance [#SRC:83c756d9-3a60-4744-a066-c56fbb204047].

question: In the context of an Issuer making an Offer of Digital Securities to the public, when and how may the Regulator treat an investment that is not otherwise a Security as a Security, and what role does the FSRA expect the Issuer’s legal advisers to play in supporting that outcome and related compliance during the Offer process?
gold_answer: For an Issuer seeking to make an Offer of Digital Securities, the FSRA expects the Issuer to consider appointing suitable legal advisers with the skills, knowledge and experience to assist the Issuer throughout the Offer process, including helping to ensure compliance with applicable provisions of FSMR and MKT and supporting the process of having the FSRA deem a Digital Security to be a Security. This expectation includes the FSRA’s general approach of direct engagement with the Issuer’s legal advisers, particularly around drafting and FSRA review of Offer documentation, so that the compliance and classification issues are addressed as part of the overall Offer workflow [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89]. In parallel, the Regulator has an express permission to act by written notice to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may do so subject to any terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. Taken together, the legal advisers’ assistance and engagement supports the Issuer in navigating the Regulator’s written-notice deeming power and any associated conditions within the Offer documentation and review process.

question: If an Issuer wants to offer Digital Securities and needs the FSRA to treat them as Securities, can the Regulator do that by written notice, and what does the FSRA expect the Issuer’s legal advisers to do during the Offer process to help with this and related compliance?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator is permitted to act by written notice to deem an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may attach any terms and conditions it considers appropriate to that deeming decision [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. In the Offer of Digital Securities context, the FSRA expects Issuers to consider appointing suitable legal advisers with the right skills, knowledge and experience to provide assistance throughout the Offer process, including helping to ensure the Issuer’s compliance with FSMR and MKT and specifically supporting “having the FSRA deem a Digital Security a Security” as part of that compliance effort [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89]. The FSRA also generally expects to engage directly with the Issuer’s legal advisers during the process, particularly on drafting and FSRA review of Offer documentation, which is where the deeming approach and any conditions can be reflected and managed in practice [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89].

question: When you calculate the Exposure value for an on-balance sheet item, what does it mean for the transaction to be “unmargined” (no variation margin exchanged), and how does that definition fit with the required Exposure value calculation methods for SFTs, Derivatives (including written credit protection), and other on-balance sheet items?
gold_answer: To apply the correct Exposure value calculation, you must (1) classify the on-balance sheet item and (2) understand whether the transaction is unmargined. A transaction is unmargined when variation margin is not exchanged; importantly, collateral other than variation margin may still be present, so the existence of some collateral does not prevent the transaction from being unmargined [#TGT:c1f17a7c-4c91-4d36-9517-a8e524a3c652]. After that definitional step, the Exposure value must be calculated using the method tied to the item type: for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the applicable netting requirements; for Derivatives (including written credit protection), it should be the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS plus an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under the specified rules; and for other on-balance sheet items, it should be based on their balance sheet values under the specified rule [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. The unmargined definition helps you focus on whether variation margin is exchanged, even where other collateral exists, while still following the required Exposure value approach for the relevant on-balance sheet category [#TGT:c1f17a7c-4c91-4d36-9517-a8e524a3c652].

question: When applying the custody-related requirements for Virtual Asset Custodians, how must the firm interpret the existing definitions of “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” so that Virtual Assets are captured, and how does this interpretation align with the requirement that “Investments” (and the related “Client Investments” references) encompass Virtual Assets for the relevant purposes?
gold_answer: A Virtual Asset Custodian must apply the custody framework on the basis that Virtual Assets are not treated as a separate, unprotected category, but are brought within the existing client property concepts. Specifically, the existing definitions of “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” must be read to include “Virtual Assets,” ensuring that the custody obligations and protections that attach to those categories also apply when the assets in custody are Virtual Assets [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7]. In parallel, for the relevant purposes, “Investment” or “Investments” must be read as encompassing “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” and this interpretive step also carries through to the corresponding references to “Client Investments,” so that any requirement framed by reference to investments is applied to Virtual Assets as well [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0]. Taken together, these readings ensure that Accepted Virtual Assets are afforded the same protections as other similar products and activities under the applicable framework, rather than being excluded due to terminology.

question: How should a Fund Manager determine whether the chapter-level requirements are excluded for it, while still being subject to the delegation and outsourcing framework that applies to Delegation Agreements and Outsourcing Agreements made under the Rules, and what is the effect of any carve-out for a Qualified Investor Fund?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager should treat the chapter-level scope statement as an exclusion from that chapter’s application to Fund Managers, because it expressly states that the chapter does not apply to Fund Managers and instead directs them to the relevant provisions and appendix within the Fund Rules framework [#SRC:77d6d088-e887-4010-b1f2-c066a0409cca]. In parallel, the Fund Manager must assess whether its activities fall within the separate delegation and outsourcing regime, which applies to a Fund Manager (and, if appointed, the Trustee) in relation to every Delegation Agreement and Outsourcing Agreement made or entered into pursuant to the Rules [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b]. This means that even where the chapter is disapplied to Fund Managers, the Fund Manager remains within scope of the appendix-based requirements when it uses delegation or outsourcing arrangements under the Rules. However, the Fund Manager must also check whether the fund is a Qualified Investor Fund, because the appendix expressly does not apply to a Qualified Investor Fund, which can remove the delegation/outsourcing appendix obligations for that fund even though the chapter exclusion for Fund Managers remains relevant [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b].

question: If the Regulator allows a delay for reporting some large or special trades, what does a Recognised Investment Exchange still have to do to publish trade price, volume and time information, and who must be told about the delay and its terms?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must set up arrangements so that the price, volume and time of transactions executed in Financial Instruments are made available to the public and the Regulator as close to real time as technically possible, based on a reasonable level of efficiency and spending on its systems. This includes making portfolio-trade information available for each constituent transaction as close to real time as possible (taking into account the need to allocate prices to particular Financial Instruments) and making public, before the next trading day opens, post-trade information for transactions that occur on the Recognised Investment Exchange outside normal trading hours [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6]. Separately, the Regulator may permit those requirements to be deferred for large volume or certain types of trades. When that permission applies, the Recognised Investment Exchange must disclose that a deferral exists and disclose the terms of the deferral to Members and users of its facilities, and to investors [#SRC:7f823646-b062-4581-a37a-a39040c4edad]. So, even with a permitted delay, it must keep the reporting framework in place and clearly communicate the deferral’s details to the specified audiences.

question: When an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to one of the specified international bodies and is considering whether it may recognise the credit risk mitigation effects of a Credit Derivative, what must it do for risk-weighting purposes, and under what provider-eligibility conditions is recognition of the Credit Derivative permitted?
gold_answer: For a CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission, an Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. Separately, if the Authorised Person is seeking to recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative in relation to that exposure, it is permitted to do so only where the Credit Derivative is provided by an eligible provider category: a central government or central bank; an MDB; an International Organisation; a PSE; banks and Securities firms that qualify for inclusion in the bank asset class; or any other entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency mapping to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. Accordingly, the mandatory 0% risk weight applies to the specified CR Exposures, while any recognition of Credit Derivative CRM effects is conditional on the provider meeting one of the listed eligibility criteria.

question: If a Non-ADGM Regulator asks for help, how can the Regulator support that request by using its Own-Initiative Powers, and how does that relate to the general idea of cooperation, assistance and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators?
gold_answer: The Target sets the overall expectation that there is a regime for cooperation, assistance and support to Non Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulators, including the exercise of power in support of those regulators [#TGT:ca98434a-5cec-42e1-a2a2-a24bb32ec523]. The Source then explains how that support can be operationalised through specific authorities in the FSMR that allow the Regulator to act on behalf of other authorities. In particular, it states that the Regulator has specific authority to exercise its Own-Initiative Powers when it is acting at the request of, or on behalf of, Non-ADGM Regulators [#SRC:30321c41-3b60-4c89-8840-ba67df61afaa]. Taken together, this means the Regulator’s support is not limited to informal cooperation; it can include using its own formal powers, but only within the defined scenario where a Non-ADGM Regulator has requested the action or the Regulator is acting on that regulator’s behalf. This links the broad cooperation concept in the Target to a concrete, permission-based power pathway described in the Source.

question: How must an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm design and operate its systems and controls so it can ensure, on an ongoing basis, that its Capital Resources remain sufficient relative to its Capital Requirement, and what must it do if those systems indicate it cannot currently meet or is unlikely to meet that capital position in the future?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must maintain systems and controls that are appropriate to provide continuous assurance that it has adequate Capital Resources to meet the applicable capital adequacy requirements at all times, and to enable it to demonstrate its capital position at any particular time if the Regulator requires that demonstration [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79]. In practical terms, those systems and controls must be capable of monitoring and evidencing that the firm’s Capital Resources equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement on an ongoing basis, because that is the required capital standard for an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e]. If, through the operation of those systems and controls, the Authorised Person forms the view that it does not currently satisfy, or is not likely to be able to satisfy in the future, the relevant capital requirement, it must immediately inform the Regulator in accordance with the applicable notification requirement [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79].

question: When the Regulator receives the notice required to initiate passporting, in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from sending the Host Regulator(s) a notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures, notwithstanding the usual five Business Day transmission expectation?
gold_answer: Upon receipt of the notice that triggers the passporting process, the Regulator is generally expected to provide notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted, and to do so within five Business Days (and subject to the stated condition in the source provision) [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. However, that transmission step is expressly prohibited in specified cases: the Regulator shall not transmit the notice if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may in the future not comply [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. The Regulator is also prohibited from transmitting the notice if it considers it necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so to further one or more of its objectives [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. In those prohibited scenarios, the usual expectation to notify Host Regulator(s) within the stated timeframe does not result in a transmission.

question: The Regulator normally has to tell the Host Regulator(s) it plans to use the passporting procedures within five Business Days after getting the required notice. When must the Regulator not send that notice anyway?
gold_answer: The process described requires the Regulator, after receiving the relevant notice, to provide notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in the Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted, and to do so within five Business Days (subject to the stated condition in the source) [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]. Even so, the Regulator is not allowed to transmit that notice in certain situations. Specifically, it shall not transmit the notice if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may in the future not comply [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. It also must not transmit the notice if it considers that refraining is necessary and appropriate to further one or more of its objectives [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. These prohibitions override the usual expectation to send the notice within the stated timeframe.

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM (including where tokens are deemed to be Securities), how should the Issuer approach the requirement to publish a Prospectus in light of the need to avoid misleading or deceptive statements or omissions, including in statements about future matters?
gold_answer: Where tokens are deemed to be Securities, an Issuer that wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM is subject to the applicable requirements for such offers, which include an obligation to publish a Prospectus as part of the regulatory treatment described in the source material [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. In preparing and publishing that Prospectus, the Issuer should ensure that the content does not contain misleading or deceptive statements or omissions, and should take particular care with any statements about future matters, because those are expressly identified as a relevant risk area in the target material [#TGT:c7e8bce4-0757-4052-b618-aedbbe7000a8]. Practically, this means the Issuer should treat the Prospectus as both a disclosure document required for an offer and a communication that must be accurate and complete: it should not omit information in a way that could mislead, and forward-looking statements should be framed so they do not create a deceptive impression. This aligns the publication obligation for offers with the expectation that disclosures avoid misleading presentation.

question: When an Authorised Person applies standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts under the FCCA to a collateralised transaction (other than an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction) that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or qualifying cross product Netting agreement, what must the Authorised Person do to calculate E* and, specifically, how must the required add on component be determined?
gold_answer: For any collateralised transaction (excluding OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions) that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, an Authorised Person using standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts under the FCCA must calculate E* as an exposure value after risk mitigation by applying the specified formula that combines: (i) E, being the fair value of the Exposure calculated in accordance with the referenced rules; (ii) C, being the fair value of eligible financial Collateral received; and (iii) an add on amount that reflects market price volatility and foreign exchange volatility [#SRC:dcbb270d-c9cc-4b97-840b-71ad5f53c4fa]. The add on itself must be calculated using one of two permitted approaches: either a formula-based approach that uses the absolute value of the net position in a given Security (ES) with an appropriate haircut (HS), and the absolute value of any net currency position different from the settlement currency (EFX) with a haircut for currency mismatch (HFX); or, alternatively, an approach using VaR models, but only where the Authorised Person has received the Regulator’s approval for that modelling approach [#TGT:6705e521-28ce-43be-8404-ffdc3b3ba923].

question: When an Authorised Person evaluates its Exposure to interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, what specific sudden and unexpected interest-rate movement must that evaluation include, and how must the evaluation be applied where the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, and that evaluation must explicitly include the effect of a sudden and unexpected parallel change in interest rates of 200 basis points in both directions [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:0dd318fb-6509-4aaf-96be-2ee00073b4c6]. This means the evaluation is not complete unless it assesses the impact of that defined shock scenario as part of the overall interest rate risk assessment for the Non Trading Book. In addition, where the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]. Accordingly, the required evaluation should be performed in a way that captures the specified parallel rate shock and is applied across the Authorised Person’s material currency exposures, ensuring the interest rate risk measurement reflects both the mandated shock coverage and the currency-by-currency measurement requirement.

question: When a Remote Body must provide the Regulator with an annual report, what reporting period should it use, and how should that period be set in relation to the prior report (or the Recognition Order if none), including the end-date mechanics and the submission timing after the period ends?
gold_answer: A Remote Body is required to provide the Regulator with an annual report, and the reporting period should align with the concept of a one-year period as the most convenient period for the report to be submitted [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757], consistent with the obligation to deliver an annual report [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814]. The period covered by each report must start on the day after the period covered by the last report; if there is no prior report, it starts after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such. The period ends on the date specified in the report, or if no date is specified, on the date of the report. If the Remote Body changes the period covered by its report, it should ensure continuity by making the first day of the new period the day immediately following the last day of the previous period. Copies of the report should be sent to the Regulator within two months after the end of the period to which the report relates.

question: A Remote Body has to send the Regulator an annual report. What time period should the report cover, how does that period start and end compared with the last report (or the Recognition Order if there was no last report), and when should the Remote Body send copies after the period finishes?
gold_answer: The Remote Body must provide the Regulator with an annual report, and the period covered should be treated as a one-year period as the most convenient approach for the report that is to be submitted [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757], matching the requirement that the report is annual [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814]. For setting the period, the start date is the day after the period covered by the last report; if the Remote Body has not previously made a report, the period starts after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such. The period ends either on a date the Remote Body specifies in the report, or, if it does not specify an end date, it ends on the date of the report itself. If the Remote Body changes the period covered by its report, it should keep the periods continuous by ensuring the first day of the new period is immediately after the last day of the previous period. Copies of the report should be sent to the Regulator within two months after the end of the period the report covers.

question: When assessing whether an application is complete, how should the Applicant sequence its submission of constitutional and governance materials, and how should it plan for the possibility that the Regulator will request additional information and engage with authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction?
gold_answer: The Applicant should treat the application as a structured package that, at a minimum, includes detailed constitutional and governance information—specifically, details of the Applicant’s constitution supported by copies of its memorandum and articles of association (or similar documents) and any agreements relating to its constitution or governance [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e]. In parallel, the Applicant should plan the procedure on the basis that submission of these baseline materials may not be the end of the information-gathering process: the Regulator is permitted to require further information from the Applicant and may also need to have discussions with the appropriate authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282]. Practically, this means the Applicant should (i) ensure the constitutional documents and related governance agreements are complete and readily explainable, and (ii) maintain an internal process to respond promptly to follow-up requests, including being prepared to facilitate or support the Regulator’s engagement with home-jurisdiction authorities. This approach aligns the initial content expectations with the Regulator’s ability to extend the information requirements during review.

question: What should the Applicant include about its constitution and governance in the application, and why should it expect the Regulator might still ask for extra details afterward?
gold_answer: The Applicant should include a clear set of constitution and governance materials in the application: details of the Applicant’s constitution, copies of its memorandum and articles of association (or similar or analogous documents), and any agreements between the Applicant, its owners or other Persons that relate to its constitution or governance [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e]. Even if those items are provided, the Applicant should expect that the Regulator may still ask for more information, because the Regulator is permitted to require further information from the Applicant and may need to have discussions with the appropriate authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282]. Procedurally, that means the Applicant should treat the initial submission as the starting point of an information exchange: keep supporting materials ready, ensure the governance documents can be explained and backed up if questioned, and be prepared to respond promptly to follow-up requests that may arise during the Regulator’s review and any related home-jurisdiction discussions.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to determine a maximum distributable amount using a multiplication approach, how should it identify the profit component that is excluded from CET1 Capital, and how does the definition of CET1 Capital affect the assessment of whether the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital falls within a particular quartile for selecting the applicable factor?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the maximum distributable amount by multiplying (i) a defined profit sum by (ii) a factor that depends on where its CET1 Capital falls within the Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. The profit sum is limited to interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after the specified actions; this requires the Authorised Person to distinguish profits that are excluded from CET1 Capital from those that form part of it [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. To make that distinction, the Authorised Person must apply the definition of CET1 Capital as the sum of specified capital elements (including qualifying capital instruments and related share premium accounts, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income, and other IFRS-disclosed reserves subject to the stated exclusions) [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb]. The same CET1 Capital definition also frames the CET1 Capital amount used to determine which quartile applies for the factor selection (0, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6), noting that the CET1 Capital considered for this purpose is the portion not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1].

question: If an Authorised Person has to work out the maximum distributable amount by multiplying a profit sum by a buffer-based factor, what counts as CET1 Capital for deciding which profits are excluded from that sum, and how does that CET1 Capital figure drive the choice of factor?
gold_answer: The calculation requires an Authorised Person to multiply a specific profit total by a factor linked to where its CET1 Capital sits within the Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. The profit total is not all profits: it is only interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent profit distribution and after the referenced actions, so the Authorised Person must first decide what is and is not included in CET1 Capital [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. CET1 Capital is defined as the sum of listed capital elements, including qualifying capital instruments and their related share premium accounts, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income (as defined in IFRS), and other IFRS-disclosed reserves, subject to the stated exclusions to avoid double counting [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb]. Once CET1 Capital is identified on that basis, the Authorised Person uses the CET1 Capital amount that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement (including any Individual Capital Requirement) to determine which quartile applies, and then applies the corresponding factor (0, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6) in the multiplication [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1].

question: If the Regulator is thinking about using its powers for a Remote Body, what process does it follow, and where do you look for the Remote Body’s notification requirements?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is considering exercising its powers in relation to a Remote Body, the process point to start with is that the Regulator will follow the approach set out by cross-reference to the listed Rules and GEN provision for that specific scenario [#TGT:731938d8-f30b-418a-91f8-bfd4da093ffa]. Separately, the notification obligations for a Remote Body are not described in that procedural statement; instead, the notification requirements are explicitly said to be set out in a particular rule dedicated to Remote Body notifications [#SRC:cf704ad8-5460-40f9-89d7-0a37da6528eb]. So, to handle the situation correctly, you should treat it as two linked checks: first, confirm and apply the Regulator’s stated approach when it is considering using its powers for a Remote Body; second, consult the specific Remote Body notification rule to understand what notifications are required and ensure they are made. This ensures you are not relying on the procedural cross-reference alone and that you also capture the standalone notification requirements that apply to the Remote Body.

question: When an Employee discloses information about suspected money laundering to a body that the Regulator treats as a relevant body—such as the FIU or another financial intelligence unit—what must a Relevant Person do to comply with its non-prejudice obligation, and how does the definition of relevant body affect the scope of protected disclosures?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must ensure it does not prejudice an Employee for making a disclosure of any information regarding money laundering to the Regulator or to any other relevant body involved in preventing money laundering [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1]. The scope of what counts as “any other relevant body” is informed by the Regulator’s view that a relevant body would include the FIU, any other financial intelligence unit, the police, or an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4]. Accordingly, the Relevant Person’s obligation extends beyond disclosures made directly to the Regulator and covers disclosures made to those bodies the Regulator considers to fall within the relevant-body concept. In practice, compliance requires the Relevant Person to treat disclosures to the FIU or another financial intelligence unit as protected in the same way as disclosures to the Regulator, and to ensure that no adverse treatment is imposed on the Employee because the Employee provided money-laundering information to any of these relevant bodies involved in prevention.

question: If an Employee reports money laundering information to the FIU (or another financial intelligence unit), what must a Relevant Person do, and why does it matter that the Regulator treats those bodies as “relevant bodies”?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must make sure it does not prejudice an Employee who discloses any information about money laundering to the Regulator or to any other relevant body involved in preventing money laundering [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1]. The Regulator’s description of what counts as a “relevant body” matters because it clarifies that the term is not limited to the Regulator itself: the Regulator considers that a relevant body would include the FIU, any other financial intelligence unit, the police, or an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4]. So, when an Employee reports to the FIU or another financial intelligence unit, that disclosure falls within the category of disclosures to a relevant body involved in prevention. The Relevant Person therefore must ensure the Employee is not treated adversely because they made that disclosure, just as if the Employee had reported directly to the Regulator.

question: Where an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission enabling it to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services undertakes the activity of a Payment Account Provider, how must it determine the Capital Requirement for that activity, and how must the Variable Capital Requirement component be calculated by reference to monthly payment volume bands?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission enabling it to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, the Capital Requirement must be calculated separately for each activity it undertakes, and for the Payment Account Provider activity it must be set as the highest of the applicable Base Capital Requirement and the relevant alternative capital measure that applies to that activity [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]. In the case of a Payment Account Provider, the relevant alternative measure is the Variable Capital Requirement, which must be calculated using a tiered, additive approach based on monthly payment volume [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4]. Specifically, the Variable Capital Requirement is the sum of percentage charges applied sequentially to bands of monthly payment volume: 2.5% on the first $10 million, 1% on the next $90 million, 0.5% on the next $150 million, and 0.25% on any remaining volume [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4]. The resulting Variable Capital Requirement is then compared against the applicable Base Capital Requirement for that activity, and the higher figure is used as the Capital Requirement for the Payment Account Provider activity [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304].

question: When applying the MIR Chapter 5 requirements to an Authorised Person Operating a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities, how must the MIR terminology be interpreted so that the correct entity is treated as subject to those requirements?
gold_answer: The compliance obligation applies to an Authorised Person that is Operating a Recognised Investment Exchange, Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities, and that Authorised Person must comply with the specified requirements set out in MIR, Chapter 5 (including the identified rules and the listed item-based circumstances) [#TGT:3fec174f-e21d-4aa0-b244-0034deb32874]. In applying those MIR Chapter 5 requirements in this context, the interpretive procedure requires that, for the relevant purposes, any MIR references to “Recognised Body” or “Recognised Bodies” are to be treated as references to “Authorised Person” [#SRC:6f13bd3c-1af7-410b-8b34-a51c343db5a3]. This ensures that where Chapter 5 provisions are framed as applying to a “Recognised Body,” they are read as applying to the Authorised Person who is operating the relevant trading venue in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities. Accordingly, the Authorised Person should map each applicable Chapter 5 requirement to itself as the responsible actor, using the required term-substitution so the obligation is implemented against the correct regulated person.

question: When an Authorised Person (and its participants) selects any delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities, what jurisdictional limits apply to where that facility may be located, and what baseline equivalence, compliance, standards, audit/control, and insurance conditions must the facility satisfy if it is outside the ADGM?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person, and its participants, must restrict their use of delivery and/or storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities to facilities located within the ADGM or in other appropriate jurisdictions, but only where those jurisdictions can meet the specified facility requirements [#TGT:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b]. Where a facility operates from outside ADGM, it must operate under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and must, at all times, comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction or elsewhere, including port conditions, customs, anticorruption, and taxation requirements, as well as any other applicable rules and regulations [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]. In addition, the facility must adhere to appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms (including IOSCO Good and Sound Practices) and maintain OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management or equivalent certification standards [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]. It must also have appropriate audit and control arrangements for inventories, deliveries, and physical infrastructure, and appropriate insurance arrangements covering operational, security, fraud, natural disasters, and other applicable risks [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5].

question: When an approval previously obtained for an issue later ceases to have effect, how must a Listed Entity treat those Securities for the purpose of determining whether it can issue additional Equity Securities without holder approval, including the impact on the Base Amount and the Relevant Issues components of the restriction formula?
gold_answer: If the approval lapses, the Securities must no longer be treated as having been issued with approval for the purpose of the issuance restriction framework; instead, they must be treated as part of the Listed Entity’s Relevant Issues tally. This reclassification matters because the restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities is calculated as (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues, and Relevant Issues is defined as Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months other than those issued with holder approval or under an exception. Once the approval lapses, the Securities cannot be counted as issued with approval for the relevant purposes and must be counted within Relevant Issues, which increases the Relevant Issues figure and correspondingly reduces the maximum number of Equity Securities the Listed Entity may issue without obtaining approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities. At the same time, because the Base Amount includes certain fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the prior 12 months with approval, the lapse means those Securities should not be supported as “with approval” for that purpose, aligning the calculation treatment with their inclusion as Relevant Issues. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: An Authorised Person can use a 0% risk weight for some CR Exposures to GCC central governments or central banks (and UAE Emirates count like GCC countries). If the needed requirements are not met, what should the Authorised Person do instead when treating that CR Exposure?
gold_answer: The permission to apply a 0% risk weight is limited to a specific set of CR Exposures: those to central governments or central banks of a GCC member country that are both denominated and funded in the domestic currency of that GCC member country; and, for this purpose, each individual Emirate of the UAE is treated as though it were a GCC member country [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1]. If the relevant requirements are not met, the CR Exposure should not be treated under that 0% risk-weight permission. Instead, the CR Exposure should be treated in accordance with the alternative rule that applies when those requirements are not satisfied [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938]. In other words, the Authorised Person should check whether the exposure fits the permitted category (correct counterparty type, GCC status including UAE Emirates, and domestic-currency denomination and funding). If it does, the 0% risk weight may be applied; if it does not, the Authorised Person must follow the other specified treatment for that exposure rather than using 0% [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1].

question: When a Listed Entity is calculating whether it is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, Equity Securities above its permitted maximum without approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities, how must it treat a prior issue that falls within the “case of (a) above” and therefore must have been approved under the relevant approval pathway? In particular, does that approval affect whether the prior issue is excluded from Relevant Issues and/or included in the Base Amount for the 12‑month calculation?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. In applying that formula, the treatment of earlier issues depends on whether they were approved under the specified approval pathway. The SOURCE establishes that, in the “case of (a) above,” the issue must have been approved under that pathway [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295]. The TARGET then links such approval to the calculation in two ways: (i) Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months “with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities” under that pathway are excluded from “Relevant Issues,” meaning they do not reduce the remaining capacity under the maximum [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]; and (ii) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the prior 12 months with approval under that pathway may be added into the “Base Amount,” increasing the reference amount used to compute the 20% limit [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. Accordingly, where the SOURCE condition applies, the approval status is determinative for both exclusions and inclusions in the TARGET calculation.

question: A Listed Entity must not issue more Equity Securities than its limit unless holders of Ordinary Securities approve it. If an earlier issue is in the “case of (a) above” and therefore must have been approved under the relevant approval route, how does that approval change the 12‑month limit calculation (what gets counted in Base Amount and what gets excluded from Relevant Issues)?
gold_answer: The TARGET sets a prohibition: a Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the stated formula unless it has approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. The SOURCE adds a specific condition about an earlier issue: in the “case of (a) above,” that issue must have been approved under the relevant approval route [#SRC:b0911de0-2418-4fb5-9565-683577084295]. That approval matters because the TARGET uses approval status to decide what counts in the 12‑month calculation. First, “Relevant Issues” excludes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the last 12 months if they were made with the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities under that approval route, so those approved issues do not reduce the remaining headroom under the maximum [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. Second, the “Base Amount” can include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the last 12 months with approval under that same approval route, which can increase the base used to compute the 20% component of the maximum [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].

question: If an Authorised Person is using the standard method for counterparty credit risk (not an internal model), how must it work out the exposure for Derivative transactions—what parts must be added together—and how does that fit with the rule that EAD for Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions must be calculated under the relevant section?
gold_answer: If the Authorised Person is not using an internal model (because it has not been granted permission by the Regulator), it must calculate exposure at default (EAD) for Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions in accordance with the relevant section under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. For Derivatives specifically, the Exposure value must be calculated as a sum: (1) the on-balance sheet value determined in accordance with IFRS, plus (2) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. This means the derivative exposure measure is not just the IFRS balance sheet amount; it must also include a forward-looking component through the prescribed add-on. In practice, when applying the standard approach without internal model permission, the EAD calculation for derivatives should reflect this combined structure—current IFRS-recognised value plus the required potential future Exposure add-on—within the section’s required framework.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by applying jurisdictional buffer rates to the locations of its exposures, how must it determine whether an exposure qualifies as a “private sector credit exposure” for that location-based weighting, and which exposure categories must be excluded from that classification?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. To apply that location-based weighting correctly, the Authorised Person must first classify which exposures are “private sector credit exposures” under the definition: these are exposures for which Credit RWAs have to be calculated in accordance with Chapter 4, but excluding exposures that fall into specified asset classes [#TGT:5d947e78-d9be-42d5-aad3-95b3528ea88c]. The excluded asset classes are Central government and central bank, Public sector enterprises, Multilateral development bank (MDB), International organisation, and Bank. Accordingly, only exposures that require Credit RWA calculation under Chapter 4 and do not fall within those excluded categories should be treated as private sector credit exposures for purposes of identifying the relevant jurisdictions and applying the applicable buffer rates in the weighted-average calculation [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] [#TGT:5d947e78-d9be-42d5-aad3-95b3528ea88c].

question: When an Authorised Person is an MTF Operator or an OTF Operator and is required to comply with the specified MIR rulebook requirements as if it were a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, how must the firm interpret any MIR/COBS Chapter 8 terminology that refers to “Investment(s)” or “Financial Instrument(s)” for the purposes of applying those obligations?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that carries on the Regulated Activity of Operating an MTF (an MTF Operator) or Operating an OTF (an OTF Operator) must comply with the listed MIR rulebook requirements that apply to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, and it must do so by reading references to Recognised Bodies or Recognised Investment Exchanges in the relevant MIR rules as references to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094]. In parallel, for the purposes of applying the relevant COBS Chapter 8 framework in this context, the firm must apply the specified interpretive substitutions: any reference to “Investment” or “Investments” is to be read as a reference to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” and any reference to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those incorporated from MIR via COBS Rule 8.2.1) is likewise to be read as “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd]. Taken together, this means the MTF Operator/OTF Operator’s compliance with the imported MIR obligations should be operationalised on the basis that the relevant COBS Chapter 8 terms are treated as Virtual Assets rather than Investments or Financial Instruments.

question: When the Regulator may require an Institution (or a class of Institutions) to suspend or remove a Financial Instrument from Trading for investor protection or orderly markets, and that action is taken without giving an affected person advance notice or a prior opportunity to make representations, what must we still provide to the affected person after the decision is made and communicated, and what must we do with any representations received within the specified period?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator exercises its power to require an Institution or a class of Institutions to suspend or remove a Financial Instrument from Trading for the purpose of protecting the interests of investors or the orderly functioning of the financial markets [#TGT:c13083a9-1aa5-43a4-805b-03a0e80a5b85], there may be circumstances in which we do not have to give an affected person advance notice of the proposed action or the chance to make prior representations before the action takes effect. In those circumstances, we are still obliged to give the affected person a right of representation within a specified period from the date on which the decision is made and communicated to the affected person [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. This is a post-decision procedural safeguard that applies even though the action has already taken effect. We are also obliged to consider any representations made by, or on behalf of, the affected person during that specified period [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. Accordingly, when using the Regulator’s trading-suspension/removal power, the process must include (i) communicating the decision to the affected person, (ii) granting a defined window for representations after communication, and (iii) actively considering any representations submitted within that window.

question: If the Regulator can tell an Institution (or a group of Institutions) to suspend or remove a Financial Instrument from Trading to protect investors or keep markets working properly, and we do this without giving the affected person notice or a chance to respond first, what right must we still give the affected person after we tell them the decision, and what must we do with what they send us?
gold_answer: The Regulator may require an Institution or a class of Institutions to suspend or remove a Financial Instrument from Trading where this is for protecting the interests of investors or the orderly functioning of the financial markets [#TGT:c13083a9-1aa5-43a4-805b-03a0e80a5b85]. Even if, in certain circumstances, we do not have to give an affected person advance notice of the proposed action or the chance to make representations before the action takes effect, we still have a continuing obligation after the decision. Specifically, once the decision is made and communicated to the affected person, we are obliged to give that person a right of representation within a specified period running from that date of decision and communication [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. During that same specified period, if the affected person (or someone acting for them) makes representations, we are obliged to consider them [#SRC:3a93267e-e3d8-4106-bfea-1af4b7310f4c]. So, even when the trading suspension/removal happens immediately, the process must still include a defined post-decision opportunity to respond and a duty on us to take those responses into account.

question: Where the Regulator does not give its approval, what procedural sequence must it follow when it is exercising its powers to refuse to make a Recognition Order or to make directions, and what limited circumstances allow it not to follow or to shorten that sequence?
gold_answer: If the Regulator does not give its approval, it must follow the specified procedure [#SRC:fabe80d0-c823-4b53-bd71-de06ee4afccf]. In the context of exercising its powers to refuse to make a Recognition Order or to make directions, that procedure requires a structured sequence: first, the Regulator gives written notice to the Recognised Body (or Applicant) explaining why it intends to take the proposed action, inviting representations, and stating the period for making them (subject to extension by the Regulator) [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. Second, it receives representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant; it will not usually consider oral representations without first receiving written representations, and will normally only hear oral representations on request [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. If a request for oral representations is refused, the Regulator must write promptly explaining why and allow further time to respond. It must then have regard to representations made and, once it has reached its decision, notify the Recognised Body or Applicant in writing. The Regulator may depart from or cut short this procedure only in the limited cases described: revocation of a Recognition Order, where the Recognised Body concerned has given its consent, or where (for a proposed direction) it considers it reasonably necessary not to follow or to cut short the procedure.

question: When a Relevant Person is conducting a customer risk-based assessment and weighing whether to assign a high-risk rating, how must it treat country or jurisdiction risk where the country is identified by a credible source as lacking effective anti-money laundering systems or as not implementing measures consistent with FATF Recommendations, and what kinds of materials and issuers qualify as a credible source for that purpose?
gold_answer: In a risk-based assessment of a customer, when considering whether to assign a high-risk rating, a Relevant Person must take into account all relevant risk factors that would reasonably apply to the customer, expressly including geographical or jurisdictional risk factors tied to whether relevant countries are identified by credible sources as not having effective systems to counter money laundering or as not implementing requirements consistent with FATF Recommendations [#TGT:938ee9c6-a91c-4702-9039-d34906f00b5c]. To apply that obligation, the Relevant Person should use the definition of “credible source,” which clarifies that credible sources include (and are not limited to) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF and by International Organisations such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, and the OECD [#SRC:d9e3fef9-b049-4b8f-9140-4d98002c3dab]. Accordingly, where a country is flagged in those types of reports by those bodies, the Relevant Person must treat that information as a relevant jurisdictional risk factor within the overall assessment, alongside other customer, product/service/transaction, and delivery-channel factors listed for consideration, and reflect it in the decision on whether a high-risk rating is warranted [#TGT:938ee9c6-a91c-4702-9039-d34906f00b5c].

question: When a Relevant Person is deciding whether to give a customer a high-risk rating, what must it do if a country linked to the customer is flagged by a credible source as weak on anti-money laundering or not aligned with FATF Recommendations, and what counts as a credible source in this context?
gold_answer: When undertaking a risk-based assessment of a customer and considering whether to assign a high-risk rating, a Relevant Person must take into account all relevant risk factors that would reasonably apply to the customer, including geographical or jurisdictional risk factors about whether the relevant country or countries are identified by credible sources as not having effective systems to counter money laundering or as not implementing requirements consistent with FATF Recommendations [#TGT:938ee9c6-a91c-4702-9039-d34906f00b5c]. To decide whether a source is “credible” for that purpose, the definition explains that credible sources include (but are not limited to) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations [#SRC:d9e3fef9-b049-4b8f-9140-4d98002c3dab]. So, if those kinds of reports from those bodies identify a country connected to the customer as weak on anti-money laundering or not aligned with FATF Recommendations, the Relevant Person must treat that as a relevant jurisdictional risk factor and weigh it as part of the overall assessment, together with the other listed customer and product/service/transaction risk factors, when deciding whether a high-risk rating is appropriate [#TGT:938ee9c6-a91c-4702-9039-d34906f00b5c].

question: If a Relevant Person sees that a country connected to a customer is described by a credible source as corrupt, linked to serious crime, or supporting terrorism, what must it consider in the customer risk assessment, and which reports and organisations can be used as credible sources?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must, during a customer risk-based assessment and when considering whether to assign a high-risk rating, take into account all relevant risk factors that would reasonably apply, including geographical or jurisdictional risk factors about whether relevant countries are identified by credible sources as having significant corruption or other criminal activity (such as terrorism, money laundering, or illicit drug production and supply) or as providing funding or support for terrorism [#TGT:938ee9c6-a91c-4702-9039-d34906f00b5c]. The definition of “credible source” for this purpose includes, but is not limited to, mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports issued by FATF, and similar reports issued by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations [#SRC:d9e3fef9-b049-4b8f-9140-4d98002c3dab]. This means the Relevant Person can rely on those types of publications from those bodies to identify jurisdictional risk, and must then factor that information into the overall assessment alongside the other listed customer and product/service/transaction risk factors when deciding whether the customer should be rated high risk [#TGT:938ee9c6-a91c-4702-9039-d34906f00b5c].

question: What does an Authorised Person that is a Branch have to do continuously to avoid a significant risk of not meeting liabilities on time, and which of the described liquidity methods can it rely on to support that continuous requirement?
gold_answer: A Branch must continuously ensure it has and maintains liquid assets and access to financial resources that are adequate in relation to the nature, size, and complexity of its business, both as to amount and quality, to ensure there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c]. The general requirement for an Authorised Person sets the same objective—ensuring there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due—and provides examples of how liquidity obligations may be met [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87]. To support the Branch’s “at all times” standard, the Branch can use these methods as building blocks for its liquid assets and financial resources: holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets, arranging an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows, and using further borrowing as part of its access to resources [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87]. The Branch must ensure the chosen combination remains adequate for its business and continues to prevent the specified risk [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c].

question: When the Regulator requests production, what documents must an Applicant be able to provide, and how does that obligation interact with the Applicant’s duty to retain specified records for a defined period after admission to the Official List?
gold_answer: An Applicant must be prepared to provide the Regulator with the documents that the Regulator requests, because the Applicant is required to provide the documents set out in the referenced list when requested to do so [#SRC:da67dd0c-a4b8-4f7d-bb9f-2eb7cd72f3d3]. To ensure it can comply with that production obligation, the Applicant must also maintain copies of a defined set of documents for six years after admission to the Official List [#TGT:78475e24-bdba-4dab-add7-238dcb871c7a]. Those retained documents include agreements to acquire assets, business or Securities connected to the issue of the Listed Entity’s Shares; documents referred to in the Prospectus or other issuance materials (such as letters, reports, valuations, contracts, or other documents); the Applicant’s constitution as at admission; annual reports and accounts for the periods forming the financial record in the Prospectus (including any guarantor); interim financial statements made up before admission; temporary and definitive documents of title; employee share scheme documents where applicable; and Board resolutions allotting or issuing the Shares. Maintaining these copies for the full retention period supports timely compliance if the Regulator later requests them.

question: If the Regulator asks for documents, what does an Applicant have to hand over, and what records must the Applicant keep for six years after admission so it can meet that request?
gold_answer: If the Regulator requests documents, an Applicant must provide the documents that the rules require it to provide when requested [#SRC:da67dd0c-a4b8-4f7d-bb9f-2eb7cd72f3d3]. To be able to do that even years later, the Applicant must keep copies of specific documents for six years after admission to the Official List [#TGT:78475e24-bdba-4dab-add7-238dcb871c7a]. The retained set covers key deal and disclosure records connected to the admission and the issue of Shares, including: agreements to acquire assets, business or Securities linked to the share issue; letters, reports, valuations, contracts and other documents referred to in the Prospectus or other issuance documents; the Applicant’s constitution at admission; annual reports and accounts for the periods included in the Prospectus financial record (and those of any guarantor); interim financial statements prepared before admission; temporary and definitive title documents; the employee share scheme document where the application relates to Securities issued under such a scheme; and Board resolutions of the Applicant allotting or issuing the Shares. Keeping these copies for the full six-year period ensures the Applicant can respond promptly if the Regulator later asks for them.

question: If an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission pays the annual supervision fee to carry on Providing Credit, when does it also have to pay an extra annual supervision fee, and how much are the two fees?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission must pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee of $100,000 to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Credit (and also to carry on Accepting Deposits) [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d]. Separately, an Authorised Person must pay the Regulator an additional annual supervision fee of $10,000 if it carries on either (a) both of the Regulated Activities referenced in the Source, or (b) the Regulated Activities of Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account and Providing Credit [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13]. Putting these together, if the Authorised Person is carrying on Providing Credit and it also falls into one of the Source situations that triggers the “additional” fee (for example, it carries on Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account as well as Providing Credit), then it must pay both amounts to the Regulator: the $100,000 annual supervision fee for carrying on Providing Credit and the extra $10,000 annual supervision fee that applies because it carries on the specified combination of Regulated Activities [#TGT:0265e5d0-471b-4c99-a867-be675e8e3f9d] [#SRC:a71386ba-eb33-4dc9-9692-dc7fb9f02b13].

question: Can the Regulator choose which Securities to admit to the Official List, and what rules must it follow when it grants that admission to the Official List it maintains?
gold_answer: Yes, the Regulator is permitted to admit Securities to the Official List and has discretion over which Securities it admits, because it may admit such Securities as it considers appropriate, but only when acting in accordance with the relevant Part [#TGT:507cd713-ca86-4535-8687-25f1305317c6]. At the same time, that discretion is not open-ended: the Regulator may only grant admission of Securities to an Official List maintained by it, and the act of granting admission must be carried out in accordance with the requirements in the FSMR and this Rulebook [#SRC:0bb34f72-20bd-464f-abe6-89c6c9ad7967]. Putting both statements together, the Regulator can decide whether particular Securities are appropriate for admission, but it must do so within the framework set by the Part referenced in the TARGET and within the additional constraints that admission is only to the Regulator’s own maintained Official List and must meet the FSMR and Rulebook requirements. In practice, the permission to admit is therefore conditional on following those governing requirements while applying the Regulator’s judgment about appropriateness.

question: In what circumstances, and subject to what notification timing conditions, must a Payment Service Provider refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer and (where applicable) restore the debited Payment Account?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider’s obligation to refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer (and, where applicable, to restore the debited Payment Account to the position it would have been in had the transaction not occurred) is triggered where an executed Payment Transaction was not authorised in accordance with the relevant authorisation standard, and the obligation is expressly stated as mandatory for the Payment Service Provider [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. However, the availability of redress under the Chapter is limited by scope conditions that apply to the Payment Service User: the Payment Service User is entitled to redress only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay after becoming aware of the unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Payment Transaction, and in any event no later than twelve months after the debit date [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. Read together, the refund-and-restoration duty operates within the Chapter’s redress framework, meaning the Payment Service User’s timely notification is a gating condition for entitlement to the redress that includes the refund to the Payer.

question: When does a Payment Service Provider have to pay back the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer, and what deadline must the Payment Service User meet to be able to get that redress?
gold_answer: The Payment Service Provider must refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer when an executed Payment Transaction was not authorised under the applicable authorisation requirement; and, if it applies, the Payment Service Provider must also restore the debited Payment Account to the state it would have been in if the unauthorised Payment Transaction had not happened [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. But the ability to obtain that outcome is not open-ended: the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Chapter only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay after it becomes aware of the unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Payment Transaction, and it must do so no later than twelve months after the debit date [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. In practice, this means the refund obligation is tied to the Chapter’s redress scope—timely notification by the Payment Service User is a condition for entitlement to the redress that includes refunding the Payer and, where relevant, restoring the Payment Account.

question: When executing an unsolicited Client order in Financial Instruments while in possession of Inside Information, in what circumstances is the person executing the order prohibited from proceeding because the Insider has disclosed Inside Information to another person outside the proper course of employment, profession or duties, and what related conduct toward the Client must also be absent?
gold_answer: A person executing an unsolicited Client order in Financial Instruments while in possession of Inside Information must treat the execution as prohibited where the relevant conduct includes an Insider disclosing Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. In the execution context, the prohibition is framed around ensuring the executor has not engaged in disclosure-based misconduct connected to the Client order: the person executing the order must not have disclosed Inside Information to the Client or procured the Client to deal in the relevant Financial Instruments (or other covered instruments) for which the executor has Inside Information, and must not have otherwise advised or encouraged the Client in relation to the transaction [#SRC:b4c8c1af-0583-4e05-88c2-d600d800e579]. Read together, the restrictions mean that execution cannot be used as a vehicle to pass Inside Information improperly (including disclosures outside proper duties) or to influence the Client’s dealing; the order must remain unsolicited and unprompted by any disclosure, procurement, advice, or encouragement by the person executing it.

question: If someone is executing an unsolicited Client order in Financial Instruments while they have Inside Information, when must they not go ahead because an Insider has shared that Inside Information with someone else outside their normal job duties, and what must they not have done to the Client?
gold_answer: They must not treat the execution of the unsolicited Client order as acceptable if the situation involves an Insider disclosing Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. In addition, the person executing the order must not have used the order process to pass on or leverage the Inside Information with the Client: they must not have disclosed the Inside Information to the Client or procured the Client to deal in the Financial Instruments (or other covered instruments) for which the executor has Inside Information, and they must not have otherwise advised or encouraged the Client about the transaction [#SRC:b4c8c1af-0583-4e05-88c2-d600d800e579].
